title: modern slavery home office vietnam albania deportations
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Exclusive: Country guidance&nbspprovided to&nbspcaseworkers to inform asylum decisions for people trafficked from Vietnam and Albania ‘significantly misleading’ and can have ‘horrendous human consequences’, experts sayThe Independent employs over 100 journalists around the world to bring you news you can trust. Please consider a contribution or subscription.Modern slavery victims are being deported to countries where they are at high risk of further exploitation because the Home Office is relying on a flawed interpretation of evidence, lawyers and researchers have warned.Guidance used by caseworkers to assess whether people trafficked to the UK can be sent back to Vietnam or Albania – the two most common nationalities for modern slavery victims in Britain – is “significantly misleading” about the risks, one told The Independent.The situation has “horrendous human consequences” if trafficking victims are refused asylum and returned to countries where they are unlikely to receive adequate protection.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesGovernment figures show 1,705 Albanians were identified as potential modern slavery victims by the UK’s National Referral Mechanism (NRM) last year, making it the most commonly referred foreign nationality, while 887 referrals were of Vietnamese origin, making it the second-most commonly referred.Victims identified through the NRM can apply for asylum if they wish to remain in the UK due to fear of returning to the country from which they were trafficked.Record high 10,000 suspected modern slavery victims in UKPotential slavery victims to be deported on charter flight to PakistanHome Office leaves modern slavery victim ‘in limbo’ for five yearsHowever, a report published last month by Asylos, a charity that produces its own reports on country-of-origin information, found many victims were at serious risk of re-trafficking in Vietnam due to economic vulnerability, problems accessing social services, stigma and unpaid debts to traffickers.It also found that recognition by the NRM as a victim of trafficking would not automatically confer the same status with officials in Vietnam, making them potentially ineligible for assistance.The report included one example of a Vietnamese boy who was trafficked from the country twice, once to China, and then once to Laos for sex exploitation, before he was found in Poland.For Albania, the Home Office’s guidance makes almost no mention of boys and young men, which experts said leads to the impression that male victims do not face any issues that would entitle them to asylum in Britain.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailHowever, Asylos last year found boys and young men in Albania are being targeted for exploitation by groups associated with organised crime, some of which have links within the UK.Trafficking victims ‘left without access to justice’ under new rulesDavid Neale, legal researcher and formerly a barrister at Garden Court Chambers, told The Independent that the Home Office guidance on both Vietnam and Albania “painted the country of origin as able to protect the person adequately when that’s very often just fundamentally not the case”.He noted that the government’s assertion that victims were likely to be able to access effective protection from the state in Vietnam was “flatly contradicted” both by the Asylos report and by some of the information included in the Home Office’s own guidelines.“It’s wholly wrong to say that in general people are going to be able to avail themselves of sufficient state protection because in a lot of cases they’re just not. They’re not going to be recognised as trafficking victims at all, and whatever services might be available are just not going to be made available to them,” he said.“Sometimes the Home Office conclusions are significantly misleading. Yet they are presented as if they are evidence when the country summary is not evidence and is in my view extremely problematic and potentially very misleading and I think does mislead a lot of people.”Mr Neale said the “misconceived” guidance was part of a “culture of refusal” within the Home Office that he said was “set up to disbelieve people and to try and paint the country of origin as able to protect the person adequately when that’s very often just fundamentally not the case”.He said negative asylum decisions based on this guidance risked “absolutely horrendous human consequences” for the victims.“They’ll go to appeal, but if they’re unrepresented or not well represented, the judge may not be cognisant of all these issues around the Home Office narrative and they just accept the Home Office narrative, and they could end up in detention – they could end up removed,” he said.“Equally, they could end up living an underground life in the UK for a long period with no access to legitimate work or benefits, which obviously makes people extremely vulnerable to re-trafficking and abuse and labour exploitation.“And even if they’re able to get legal representation to appeal, people can be waiting months or years for their appeal, during which they’re likely to be on a minimal level of support – unable to work and claim mainstream benefits. title: how parentteacher collaboration is helping pupils back to school safely
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The groundbreaking work of Derbyshire’s Embark Federation is a roadmap for reopening classrooms while putting the well-being of children firstIn association with the UK GovernmentThe end of lockdown schooling and the return to the classroom for pupils across the UK is understandably a front-of-mind issue for every anxious parent.There are understandably important questions regarding what it will look like and what safety measures will be introduced.But the groundbreaking work of the Embark Federation not only offers some reassuring answers concerning pupil safety, but also highlights that a collaborative approach between teachers and parents is key to its success.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesReconnection to Recovery and Resilience programmeThe Embark Federation family of nine schools across Derbyshire has a collective goal: working as a team, to create schools that stand out at the heart of their communities. It has four core beliefs: family, integrity, teamwork and success – all integral pillars of its Reconnection to Recovery and Resilience programme.Put together by Sharon Gray OBE and the federation’s head teachers, it’s designed to welcome pupils back to class after lockdown. “Everybody in the Embark community has done their bit,” says Gray, a headteacher for 20 years, mostly in special schools supporting youngsters experiencing social, emotional and mental health difficulties and schools going through challenges.“It’s been all hands on deck,” executive headteacher and Trust leader of Embark’s schools Matthew Crawford adds. “Even two weeks into lockdown we were thinking about our children returning to school, whatever date that may be.”Safety at school1. Anyone who is unwell or been in contact with somebody showing coronavirus symptoms should stay away from schools, colleges and childcare settings2. Hands should be cleaned more often than usual with soap and running water for at least 20 seconds and dried thoroughly. Alternatively, hand sanitiser or alcohol hand rub can be used3. Promote the ‘catch it, bin it, kill it’ approach to coughing and sneezing4. Clean frequently touched surfaces regularly using standard products, such as detergent and bleach5. Help to minimise contact and mixing by altering classroom layout and timetablesWith regards to physical changes that parents and pupils can expect to see in corridors and classrooms, Embark is working with Government guidance and undertaking a thorough, bespoke risk assessment for each of its schools. “It can’t be a one-size-fits all approach,” Crawford stresses.According to Anna Upton – head of the 240-pupil Chaucer Junior School in Ilkeston, Derbyshire – questionnaires were sent out to reconnect with parents, through which they could express concerns and suggest ideas about the return to classrooms.According to Upton, staggered breaks and how drop-offs will work were important issues that were flagged in questionnaires. “But the risk assessment the Trust has put in has allowed us to make a comprehensive plan and we can communicate that to the parents,” she explains.“What the Trust have done with the programme is to implement nine stages which support our schools to open as safely as possible, supporting the staff parents and the children. The risk assessment means that I, as a headteacher, can do what’s right for my school.”Chair of trustees Sarah Armitage emphasises the importance of teamwork based around a guiding principle: families first. We look after families, so we reach out we talk.” she says.“Then there’s teamwork. Let’s harness the power of the team so it’s not the headteacher sitting by themselves with all these things to think about – that load is shared.”Armitage’s back-to-school outlook is optimistic too: “We have created something with this programme that we hope will be massively beneficial. Our role as leaders is to keep that going, carry on putting emotional needs at the heart of everything we do, because then children are able to learn and benefit – and move through this crisis.”Information in this article applies to schools in England only. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Maker of household names including Ben &amp Jerry’s, Domestos and Dove to move legal base to LondonUnilever, the maker of a host of brands including Marmite and Ben &amp Jerry’s, is to combine its Dutch and UK businesses in one company based in London after U-turning on a previous decision to move its headquarters to Holland.The consumer goods giant announced on Thursday it would scrap its dual Anglo-Dutch structure, which has been in place for 90 years.Unilever said that it will maintain its presence in both the Netherlands and the UK, with no plans to cut jobs. Headquarters in both countries will not be affected but the company’s legal base will switch to London.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesBusiness Secretary Alok Sharma tweeted that the decision was a “clear vote of confidence in the UK”.Unilever was forced into an embarrassing U-turn in 2018 after announcing plans to move its headquarters from London to Rotterdam and ditch its listing on the London Stock Exchange. Nestle and Unilever ‘linked to Indonesian forest fires’Some shareholders objected to the proposals which were later ditched, with former chief executive, Paul Polman, and previous chair, Marijn Dekkers, both quitting soon after.After the new legal entity is established in the UK, Unilever plans to keep its main stock market listing in London with secondary listings in Amsterdam and New York. The company revealed it had not consulted Dutch shareholders about the plan, meaning there is a possibility they could block it, as British shareholders did in 2018.Its unusual dual structure emerged in 1930 after British soap manufacturer Lever Brothers merged with Dutch firm Margarine Unie to create Unilever.Establishing the new setup will simplify the business, with board members meeting in London rather than alternating between two headquarters in different countries.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Almost 210,000 coronavirus cases have been confirmed in New York City alone since the US pandemic began, according to the US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesWhilst one million Americans contracted the virus within the initial three months of the pandemic, the past one million cases were contracted within six weeks, according to the data. California, Texas, Florida, North Carolina, and Arizona are among 20 states with more cases on average in the past week, according to New York Times analysis. Arizona alone has seen, on average, more than 1,000 new cases each day this week. title: china pangolins traditional medicine coronavirus animal trade
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Some scientists believe pangolins incubate the Covid-19 virusThe Independent employs over 100 journalists around the world to bring you news you can trust. Please consider a contribution or subscription.China has removed pangolin parts from its list of traditional medicines, state-backed media reported, in a move campaigners say is a vital step in helping to protect the endangered animal.Pangolins – the world’s most trafficked mammal  – are highly sought after in China and Vietnam for their meat which is considered a delicacy, while their scales are used in traditional medicine and folk remedies.Similar in size to domestic cats and the only mammal covered in scales, all eight pangolin species are protected under international laws but there remains a growing illegal trade of the animals. Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThis week health authorities omitted pangolin scales from China’s latest Pharmacopoeia, an approved list of traditional drugs and remedies due to “wild resources exhaustion”, according to a report in the Health Times.WildAid CEO Peter Knights said the move was “the greatest single action that could have been taken to save pangolins from extinction.”“The increased protection coupled with the swift and comprehensive closure of live wildlife markets and removal of many wild species from the list of what can be consumed as food in China were already very positive steps to saving the pangolin worldwide and reducing the possibility of them ever being a vector for disease.“And now this announcement, effectively the closure of legal sales of pangolin scales, shutting the last major loophole in pangolin protection efforts,” he added.People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals (PETA) welcomed China’s decision, but urged action to stop the sale of pangolins on the black market. “PETA gives a nod to China for taking an important step to combat the demand for pangolin scales,” director Elisa Allen told The Independent.“However, as long as it remains desirable and profitable for endangered animals’ body parts to be sold for medicine, wildlife will continue to be killed on the black market.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by email“We urge the Chinese government to clamp down on the use of animal-derived substances for medicine – whether it’s pangolin scales, donkey skin for ejiao, or horse urine for Premarin, which is also an issue in the West.”The move comes after China’s forestry authority last week upgraded the status of pangolins to “first-level protected wild animal,” the highest possible protection status alongside pandas and tigers.Trade in pangolins is banned in China but it is estimated that between 116,990 and 233,980 were killed between 2011 and 2013, according to the World Wildlife Fund, but experts fears those numbers are just the tip of the iceberg.Last year alone, authorities seized more than 130 tons of pangolin related products, a figure estimated to represent up to 400,000 animals, according to conservation group WildAid.Gilbert Sape, Head of Traditional Medicine at World Animal Protection called for a permanent ban on wildlife trade, saying it wwas ”the only long-term solution to keeping wild animals wild, eliminating animal suffering, and all importantly, preventing major health epidemics.”Pangolins eat ants, termites and larvae. Some scientists believe they may incubate the Covid-19 virus that is thought to have emerged in Wuhan last year and has since swept the globe.Scientists find virus similar to Covid-19 in pangolinsFollowing the outbreak of coronavirus at the end of last year, China banned the consumption of all wild animals in a bid to prevent further outbreaks but many wet markets have since reopened.Earlier this year, The Independent renewed its call for the banning of trade in wild animals to help protect endangered species and avoid future pandemics.“These actions of China will have a real impact, these are steps that were critical, that needed to be taken if real conservation was going to happen for these animals,” said David Olson, director of Conservation at WWF Hong Kong.“Most of the demand for pangolin is coming from traditional Chinese medicine and consumption. That’s what is driving this large scale illegal trade.”With additional reporting by Louise Boyle Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Scientists use drones as new method for counting turtles, producing more accurate resultsScientists have discovered that the world’s largest population of green turtles is nearly twice as big as previously thought, after drones allowed them to observe the animals better.About 64,000 nesting green turtles were filmed waiting to lay their eggs on Raine Island, a vegetated coral cay located on the outer edges of the Great Barrier Reef.Australian researchers from the Great Barrier Reef Foundation’s Raine Island Recovery Project said using a drone helped them accurately count thousands of turtles, a task too difficult to do “from a small boat in rough weather”.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesTheir findings, which were published in scientific journal PLOS ONE, compared three methods for counting the turtles as they made their way to the nesting grounds on Raine Island.Richard Fitzpatrick, a research partner from the Biopixel Oceans Foundation, said previous vessel-based counts were inaccurate.‘Two bin lorries a day’ of microfibres entering European waterwaysDavid Attenborough says saving the planet ‘is within reach’ Whoopi Goldberg voices animated short from Extinction RebellionFive surprising things you never knew contained plasticPPE washes up off French coast“When we compared drone counts to observer counts, we found that we had under-estimated the numbers in the past by a factor of 1.73.“By using drones, we have adjusted historical data. What previously took a number of researchers a long time can now be accomplished by one drone operator in minutes.”The paper’s lead author Dr Andrew Dunstan, of the Queensland Department of Environment and Science, said: “Previous population survey methods involved painting a white stripe down the green turtle’s carapace when they were nesting on the beach, then getting on a small boat and counting painted and non-painted turtles.“Our eyes are attracted much more to a turtle with a bright white stripe than an unpainted turtle, but the pain washed off after a few days and the counting accuracy suffered.“Trying to accurately count thousands of painted and unpainted turtles from a small boat in rough weather was difficult. Using a drone is easier, safer, much more accurate and the data is permanently stored,” he added.Managing director of the Great Barrier Reef Foundation, Anna Marsden, congratulated the researchers and described the images produced by the drone as “extraordinary”.“Raine Island is the world’s largest green turtle nesting site and that’s why we’re working with our Raine Island Recovery Project partners to protect and restore the island’s critical habitat,” she said.“We’re taking action to improve and rebuild the island’s nesting beaches and building fences to prevent turtle deaths, all working to strengthen the island’s resilience and ensure the survival of our northern green turtles and many other species.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Schools are reducing class sizes, shortening lessons and staggering arrival timesThe Independent employs over 100 journalists around the world to bring you news you can trust. Please consider a contribution or subscription.As the government continues to flip-flop over its plans to reopen schools in England, provoking uncertainty and anger among the education sector, other countries across the world have already succeeded in sending children back to class.Earlier this week, education secretary Gavin Williamson admitted that not all pupils would be able to return before the summer, with some having to wait until September, despite initial aims to begin the phased reopening of all primary schools from 1 June.  In contrast, thousands of children in countries such as Denmark, Germany, France, South Korea and China have been back in class for weeks. Here, we take a look at what the rest of the world is doing:Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHaving passed through the worse of the crisis, China was one of the first countries to start reopening its schools. In the far-western provinces, some have been opened since mid-March, though the vast majority started welcoming students back last month. Class sizes have been reduced, lessons shortened and arrival times staggered to limit the risk of transmission.Schools in cities with large populations, such as Beijing and Shanghai, are running classes with a maximum of 20 students to allow social distancing. Pupils have also been told to walk or be driven to school by their parents, in order to avoid busy public transportation like the subways.Teachers are taking students’ temperatures before they enter buildings while thermal scanners have been introduced in some schools those with a fever are sent home.How to help the elderly and vulnerable during the coronavirusHow to feel less anxious about the coronavirusHow to be productive when working from home during coronavirusWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?The dirty truth about washing your handsA country that has been credited with its rapid and effective Covid-19 response, South Korea began reopening its high schools last month. On 8 June, lower-level pupils started returning to school in phased steps.Under new sanitation rules, students and teachers must wear masks except at mealtimes and clean their desks, which are spaced 1 metre apart and have been fitted with plastic partitions in some schools.Like China, authorities in South Korea have turned to thermometers to help monitor the temperature of pupils and teachers. And if any student tests positive for the virus, the entire school is expected to switch to online classes for at least two weeks.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailIt has been far from straightforward though. More than 500 schools were last month forced to close just days after they had re-opened, due to a spike in cases in Seoul and its surrounding metropolitan area.With responsibility for education devolved to the country’s 16 federal states, some regions have been moving quicker than others in opening schools.In general, younger students and those with exams to sit have been prioritised in returning to class. Schools in some states have been opened since 27 April to allow pupils to take their tests.To reduce the risk of transmission, class sizes have been cut in half, one-way systems enforced in corridors, and lunch breaks staggered.Many states are aiming to have all classes in schools and kindergartens return before the start of the summer break, which starts as early as 22 June in some parts of the country.Denmark was the first European country to reopen primary schools and kindergartens, doing so in mid-April. Secondary students started returning to class on 18 May.Denmark reopens schools and shops, sparking concerns from parentsYounger pupils are expected to remain in “protective bubbles”, which keeps them from mixing with other teachers and groups of children. They use different entrances to their fellow pupils and must wash their hands at least every two hours. Outside teaching has also been implemented where possible.Christian Wejse, an associate professor in the Department of Infectious Diseases at Aarhus University Hospital, said the country had not seen an increase in the rate of transmission after schools were reopened.Since the country’s lockdown was lifted on 11 May, 40,000 primary schools have reopened, along with some secondary schools. So far, around one in five primary school pupils has returned to class. Priority has been given to the children of key workers.Teachers and children over 11 are expected to wear masks and class sizes have been limited to 15 pupils. Schools in the worst-affected regions of France, such as Paris, remain closed.Nursery children in France forced to play in isolation chalk squaresSweden: In keeping with country’s soft-touch approach to lockdown, schools have remained open during the pandemic. Authorities have relied on social distancing and hygiene measures to reduce the spread of infection instead.India: The government is planning to reopen the country’s schools and colleges in a phased manner after 15 August. As part of plans that are being formulated by officials, India’s 270 million students may be required to attend classes on alternative days.Israel: Over 20 more schools were closed earlier this month after the country recorded the largest single day rise in infections. According to the Education Ministry, 87 schools and daycares have now been closed to stem the spread of the virus.South Africa: Students in their final years of primary and secondary school started returning to class on 9 June, after an initial delay to the restart date amid teachers’ concerns there was a shortage of sufficient masks and gloves. title: belgium king leopold statue who colonial africa congo black lives matter
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The Independent employs over 100 journalists around the world to bring you news you can trust. Please consider a contribution or subscription.When it comes to ruthless colonialism and racism, few historical figures are more notorious than Leopold II, the king of the Belgians who held Congo as his personal property and may have been responsible for the deaths of millions of Congolese more than a century ago.Yet across Belgium, the monarch's name is still found on streets and tunnels. Cities are dotted with his statues and busts, even as evidence of his misdeeds has piled up over the decades.Now a reckoning seems to be at hand.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe protests sweeping the world after George Floyd's killing in the US have added fuel to a movement to confront Europe's role in the slave trade and its colonial past. Leopold is increasingly seen as a stain on the nation where he reigned from 1865 to 1909. Demonstrators want him removed from public view.In just the last week, a long-running trickle of dissent that resulted in little more than occasional vandalism has turned into a torrent, with statues of Leopold defaced in a half-dozen cities. In the port town of Antwerp, where much of the Congolese rubber, minerals and other natural riches entered the nation, one statue was burned and had to be removed for repairs. It is unclear whether it will ever come back.Statue of slave trader Edward Colston fished out of Bristol HarbourChristopher Columbus statue set alight, thrown in lake by protestersConfederate statue removed from Florida park“When you erect a statue, it lauds the actions of who is represented. The Germans would not get it into their head to erect statues of Hitler and cheer them,” said Mireille-Tsheusi Robert, president of the Congolese action group Bamko-Cran, which wants all Leopold statues removed from Belgian cities. “For us, Leopold has committed a genocide.”Similar efforts are unfolding in Britain, where at least two statues of prominent figures connected to the slave trade have been taken down by protesters or city officials. London's mayor has promised a review of all monuments.Leopold ruled Congo as a fiefdom, forcing many of its people into slavery to extract resources for his personal profit. His early rule, starting in 1885, was famous for its brutality, which some experts say left as many as 10 million dead.After his ownership of Congo ended in 1908, he handed the central African country over to the Belgian state, which continued to hold sway over an area 75 times its size until the nation became independent in 1960.Leopold has come to symbolise the racism and inequality citizens of Congolese descent have had to endure. Next to the royal palace stands an equestrian statue with Leopold gazing solemnly towards the horizon. On Wednesday, his hands and eyes were covered with red paint, and expletives were spray-painted on the side of the monument.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailMaximilian Christiaens, an architect with a Congolese mother and Belgian father, who came to see the statue after the defacing, realises the issue is part of his identity. Since Congo achieved independence, Belgium's Congolese population has swelled to about 230,000 in a nation of 11 million.“You know, we feel at home here, but seeing symbols like this in the city and all over the country gives us the opposite signal,” Mr Christiaens said. He would like to see them torn down.A similar struggle is playing out in the majestic woods east of Brussels in Tervuren, where the palatial Royal Museum for Central Africa stands. It was built over a century ago to glorify Leopold's colonial exploits and to convince Belgium citizens that their country was delivering civilisation to the heart of wild Africa.Museum director Guido Gryseels fully understands the challenges and the sensitivities, especially after a Leopold statue was defaced in the gardens outside the museum last week. He has sought to shift the museum's views on colonialism into a contemporary reassessment of a flawed past. This week, the Black Lives Matter logo was displayed on digital screens at the museum entrance.As part of a major renovation he oversaw, Mr Gryseels consigned the racist statues of Congolese and the glorifying busts of the Belgian military to the “depot” of outdated sculptures in the museum's cellars.“We wanted to keep them somewhere so that the visitors could still see, so that we could explain: 'This is how we looked at Africa before,'” Mr Gryseels said.Oxford University head warns against ‘hiding history’ in statue rowBanksy suggests replacement for toppled statue of Bristol slave traderMuseums and cinemas reopen in Denmark as Copenhagen eases lockdownUpstairs, in the grand rooms, the only bust of Leopold on display is made of ivory and aims to explain how the plunder of the country extended to the wholesale slaughter of elephants.As a listed architectural treasure, Leopold's royal double L monogram is still plastered all over the building. But Congolese artists have been asked to make a counterpoint, and in the main hall now stands a sculpture of a skull of a Congolese chief who was beheaded by a Belgian. In front of statues that could not be moved because they were protected, there are now transparent drapes with images criticising Belgian actions in Congo.“It would have been impossible 30 years ago, but there is a step forward,” Ms Robert said. Still, she said the changes do not go far enough and the museum needs to better embrace Congolese in its management structure.Just about everybody acknowledges that Belgian society needs to take a hard look at its past. The Catholic church, the dominant force in education during much of Belgium's existence, was at worst an active participant in colonialism, at best a passive bystander. And since many Belgians had family members who went to Congo to seek their fortunes, there is a sense of unease in confronting the history of racism and exploitation.“The amnesia is linked to the money the Belgians made in Congo,” Ms Robert said.For many years, Belgian colonial authorities peddled the idea that the king went to Congo to stop the slave trade, Mr Gryseels said, when it was really “a pretext to make big economic gains”.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The company said it had to comply with applicable laws in ChinaVideo conferencing software maker Zoom shut down the account of Chinese activist Zhou Fengsuo at the behest of the Chinese government.The account was closed because Zhou, and other activists, held a digital event commemorating the Tienanmen Square Massacre.The Tienanmen Square protests were a student movement for democratic rights in the country set against mass privatisation and neoliberal globalism enacted by Deng Xiaoping, according to historian and participant in the 1989 protest Wang Hui. Thousands of people were killed and wounded when , in what came to be known as the Tienanmen Square Massacre.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesZhou had paid for a Zoom account associated with the U.S. nonprofit Humanitarian China.On 31 May, 250 people signed in to the meeting, including mothers of students killed in the 1989 event.Man sentenced to death on ZoomOn 7 June, however, Zhou found that his Zoom account displayed a message that it had been shut down in a screenshot seen by Axios.Zhou had not been able to access his account, and Zoom had not been responding to his emails. Reportedly, Zoom also closed the account of former Hong Kong politician Lee Cheuk Yan in late May.“We are outraged by this act from Zoom, a U.S company,” Zhou and other organisers said in a statement.“As the most commercially popular meeting software worldwide, Zoom is essential as an unbanned outreach to Chinese audiences remembering and commemorating Tienanmen Massacre during the coronavirus pandemic.”In response, Zoom said that it had to comply with local law and has reactivated the account.Created with Sketch.Gadget and tech news: In pictures Show all 25Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.125 Gun-toting humanoid robot sent into spaceRussia has launched a humanoid robot into space on a rocket bound for the International Space Station (ISS). title: cinemas theatres reopen uk
story: CINEMAS and theatres have been closed since the the beginning of the coronavirus lockdown in March. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has now laid out a timetable for getting the UK moving again in a -page plan - and the screen and stage couldduring the summer.Several drive-in cinemas will open from June , following a statement from the PM.At the Drive In, Luna Cinema, and Pub in the Park are all offering drive-in screenings across the UK, but won’t be starting until the beginning of July.Luna Cinema will host drive-in cinema nights at a number of venues including Allianz Park in London, Warwick Castle in the Midlands, Knebworth House in Herts and Bleinheim Palace in Oxford.More venues are expected to be revealed soon.All cars will be two metres apart and all food will be pre-ordered to minimise contact.The Drive In has planned film screenings, stand-up comedy and live music at the Troubadour Meridian Water in Enfield, starting July .Tom Kerridge’s Pub in the Park will launch Drive  Dine Theatre at Syon Park and Selhurst Park Stadium in London.Films on show will include Jaws, Aladdin, , Knives Out and Back to the Future.Sunset Cinema at Twyford Avenue Sports Ground in London will be showing Bohemian Rhapsody, La La Land, Grease, Joker and The Lion King.Other venues include Birmingham, Manchester, Leeds and Newcastle.Suffolk’s Helmingham Hall near Stowmarket will also welcome Brits to screenings in July with live entertainment and classic movies from the s.Cinemas could be opened as part of the third step of the governments three stage plan to reopen the UK amid the coronavirus pandemic.It is hoped some leisure facilities will be able to open from July  at the absolute earliest - with cinemas being explicitly named in the documents.In the plan released on May , the government said: The ambition at this step is to open at least some of the remaining businesses and premises that have been required to close.It added: They should also meet the Covid- Secure guidelines.Some venues which are, by design, crowded and where it may prove dficult to enact distancing may still not be able to re-open safely at this point, or may be able to open safely only in part.Nevertheless the Government will wish to open as many businesses and public places as the data and information at the time allows.All measures laid out in the new blueprint are dependent on how successfully the UK can control the virus, and social distance measures will still be in place.Mr Johnson has said he will slam on the brakesit looks like Britain is being threatened by a second wave of infections.Vue Cinemas is planning for a reopening on July  and will introduce a string of measures to make it safe for staff and customers.Tickets will only be able to be booked online to make sure that only viewers who live in the same household will sit together in groups.It will also stagger film times to help maintain social distancing rules between screens.The chain said enhanced cleaning and employee protection protocols will be introduced.They added: Big screen entertainment is a force for good in society, providing an accessible and controlled way for families to begin to enjoy le outside their homes and we are excited to be able to start planning for a future where we can enjoy movies together again.Tim Richards, head of Vue, previously said he hoped to open up screens again in time for the release of Dark Knight director Christopher Nolan’s new film, the £ million high-concept blockbuster Tenet - slated for release on July .The live-action version of Mulan and new James Bond film No Time To Die are also set to be screened this summer after being put on hold due to the virus.Theatres are also folded into step three of the plan - meaning they will open from July  at the very earliest.Stage fans however may have a chance to view live-streamed or broadcast productions of shows during step two.The second stage guidance includes options for cultural events to occur behind closed doors.It is currently unclear how this would work as industries across the UK to try work out how to adapt to the new normal.Some shows, such as the Menier transfer of the Jane Austen adaptation The Watsons to the Harold Pinter theatre, which was due in May, had to be cancelled due to the pandemic.Others, like To Kill A Mockingbird at the Gielgud, have been postponed.In early May, theatre producer Sir Cameron Mackintosh said the lockdown measures mean West End theatres are unlikely to reopen until .Playwright James Graham was even less hopeful.He says the theatre wont survive without an “aggressive government bailout”.The Government has released its road map to ease us out of the nationwide restrictions - starting on Wednesday, May , with unlimited exercise and some sectors such as construction and manufacturing making a limitedto work.Mr Johnson unveiled the three-step plan during an address to the nation on Sunday, May .Along with it he also revealed the Covid Alert System, which offers five tiers of warning levels indicating the severity of the virus.Britain is currently in level four - and it is hoped the colour-coded alerts will help people known how strict they have to be on social distancing measures.Some changes have already been rolled out for day-to-day le, with people now told to wear face coverings on public transport.Theatres and cinemas are likely to feature in the later stages of these plans for normal le to resume.Despite ongoing fears, cinema boss Mr Richards is confident huge multiplex cinemas will be able to observe social distancing measures when movie-goers .He said: We can actually control how many people go into our cinema at any given time.We have the ability to schedule our films separately and control entrances and exits for customers.”Little has been said about whether theatres will be able to do the same.However, behind the scenes, there has been a lot of discussion on the issue.In an opinion piece which appeared in The Stage, it was suggested that theatre-goers will need to be separated by two metres, while actors would be required to perform from opposite ends of the stage.Intervals could also be extended to  minutes as it would take so long to get to the bar.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus lockdown rules family friends
story: LOCKDOWN changes from June  will see single adults be able to meet with other households after weeks of being alone.Boris Johnson announced further relaxing of lockdown measures on June  during a coronavirus press briefing.Yes,youre a single adult - living alone or with a person under  - you can now join another household.On June , Boris Johnson revealed a new plan for support bubbles for single people living alone, who are strugglingThe PM said: There are too many people, particularly those who live by themselves who are lonely and struggling with being unable to see friends and family.From this weekend we will allow single adult households, living alone, or single parents with children under , to form a support bubble with one other household.They will be able to move in togetherthey wish, or travel between each others homes.Also, they can hug, go into each others homes, and even stay overnight.Plus they wont have to stay m apart and can act asthey live in the same home.They dont have to move in together but can dothey wish, or travel between each others homes.In May, Mr Johnson announced that groups of up to six will be allowed to meet outside in parks and gardens from Monday, June  – meaning friends and families can see each other for the first time in months.Some group sports will also be back on the cards, with golf games and tennis matches of up to four people permitted from June .Mr Johnson said: “We will now allow people to meet in gardens and other outdoor spaces. This means friends and families can now see their loved ones.“I know for many this will be a long awaited and joyful moment.”Brits, who are not from single households must still maintain social distancingthey do meet up, and there are a number of restrictions they must abide by.Hugging is not allowed, as is sitting on the sofa, lingering inside and indoor dinner parties.You can however use the toilet during your visit, and as long as you maintain a two-metre distance, groups of up to six people from dferent households can meet outside - meaning BBQs are back on the menu.The Prime Minister urged Brits to “avoid seeing people from too many households in quick succession” and said people should keep the number of households they interact with to a minimum.He was also quick to stress that the Government will monitor the nations rate of infection and reimpose restrictionsnecessary.The tweaked rules will only apply in England - as Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland will follow slightly dferent guidelines as they have a higher rate of infection.Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick has already ordered all parks to keep their gates open and put an end to council patrols stopping people from catching rays and sitting on benches.Police were previously allowed to issue on the spot fines of £ for meeting without a good reason, and this has been increased to £ following Boris Johnsons announcement on Sunday, May .Social distancing rules continue to be even stricter for over-s and those with serious underlying health conditions such as a weakened immune system, chronic respiratory disease or chronic heart disease.On May , it was confirmed that the vulnerable people having to shield would be able to leave their homes the following day, but would have to remain social distanced and it is advised only seeing one person from another householdthey live alone.Some of these rules have been relaxed but they remain dependent on the R rate staying lower than one.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Mr Johnson has encouraged Brits to do “more and even unlimited amounts of outdoor exercise”.People are allowed to sit in their local park, drive to other destinations, and play sports.The Prime Minister stressed people must continue to “obey the rules on social distancing”.To enforce those rules police will be increasing fines for people who break them.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: madeleine mccann latest news update
story: Christian B has been named as the prime suspect in the investigation after the three-year-old went missing in Portugal in .The convicted paedo, , is currently serving time for drugs and rape in Kiel prison in Schleswig-Holstein, Germany.The states justice minister, Claus Christian Claussen, said: He is in a single cell for Christian Bs safety and security against possible attacks from other inmates.Madeleine is believed to have been murdered soon after she was kidnapped, the German prosecutor leading the investigation has said.This comes after a British ex-girlfriend of Christian B claimed the night before the toddler vanished he told her: “I have a horrible job to do in Praia da Luz tomorrow.”She also said how she asked himhe snatched Madeleine McCann and he warned: “Just don’t go there.”Follow our live blog below for all the latest news and updates.CHRISTIAN B main suspect in the Madeleine McCann case is receiving counselling in prison, it has been revealed.Justice minister of the northern state of Schleswig-Holstein, told a parliamentary hearing yesterday that Christian B, , was being given counselling for a #special psychological situation#.He is currently in solitary confinement in a prison at the northern town of Kiel to stop inmates attacking him.THE boss and former pal of Madeleine McCann suspect Christian B sensationally claimed #we all know# what happened to the missing tot.Tiziano Ilg hired the fellow German at his restaurant when the paedophile suddenly turned up in the remote village of Foral in the weeks following Maddies disappearance.Ilg, now in his late s and still living in the region, has kept a low profile since German police identied his old worker as a prime suspect in Maddies case.And its understood he has not spoken to police about his fellow countryman.Read the full story here.MET POLICE have received nearly , tips in the past week about Madeleine McCann.It follows last weeks revelation that Christian B was the main suspect in the case.Scotland Yard said today it had received  pieces of information following the fresh appeal.People were asked to contact cops they recognised a VW camper van or a Jaguar used by Christian B.And detectives also asked about two phone numbers, one of which was used by Christian B, and one to call him.A BRIT ex-girlfriend of Christian B was #shocked and horried# when she heard he was a suspect in the Madeleine McCann investigation.She told The Mirror: #I couldn’t believe I had been with someone who could be capable of that.“To imagine I’ve been with someone who is capable of hurting someone like that is sickening.“It’s so hard for me to believe it’s true.#She added: “There was absolutely no sign of him being into young children or young girls.#COPS in Portugal wont search any of Christian Bs former homes until asked to by German police, it is reported.He had stayed at a villa in Floral, about  miles from Praia da Luz, where Madeleine disappeared in , as well as a remote villa in the hills above the coastal resort.A senior source in the Portuguese police told Thethey are waiting until they receive a request from Germany to search any properties connected to Christian B.The source told the paper: #We will do what they say.#CHRISTIAN B is a prolic burglar, who has previous convictions for sex crimes against young girls.He was was born in Germany in  but moved to Portugal in his late teens.The main suspect in the Madeleine McCann case # who was  at the time of her disappearance # has twice been convicted for sex crimes against young girls.German police # who are treating the case as a murder inquiry # believe he initially planned to rob the holiday apartment before he #moved on to a sexual motive#.He was already known to British and Portuguese police in relation to Madeleines disappearance in Praia da Luz.The latest information came from a witness who stepped forward following the appeal by the Met Police on the tenth anniversary in .Christian B has been linked with the disappearances of several children over the past  years, including that of a six-year-old boy in Portugal in  and a five-year-old girl in Germany in .Authorities in Belgium have also linked him to the murder of missing -year-old Carola Titze, who disappeared while on holiday in De Haan on July , .THE sister of another former girlfriend of Christian Bs said he beat and abused her during their -month relationship.The ex, now , has been interviewed by German cops about the suspect and is being cared for by a social worker.She got together with Christian B in Germany when she was  and he was .Her sister said the family are now living in fear of the convicted paedophile and have spoken to the police about him.The sister told MailOnline: #He hit my sister. It was horrible for her.#CHRISTIAN B also brutally beat a British girlfriend during their fling # which lasted less than a year # slamming her head against a wall in the ladies toilets of bar where she worked.They had become friends in the Spring of , with the woman describing him as very charming and the relationship as very nice.The petite barmaid incredibly forgave Christian B after her New Year’s Day beating # but dumped him in mid- when she found women’s underwear in his bag.The suspect # who is  now # is believed to have been leading a #transient lestyle# at the time of Madeleines disappearance, as he travelled between Portugal and Germany.CHRISTIAN B  wrote an #eloquent, meticulously written# note to a German newspaper asking it to cover his rape trial last year, it is reported.He is said to have written to the Braunschweiger Zeitung after being accused of raping a -year-old woman in Portugal in .The Daily Mail reports he moaned the case wasnt in the public interest because of #arbitrary decisions being taken by the authorities#.At the trial in Germany last December he was found guilty and sentenced to seven years.He is appealing the conviction.CHRISTIAN B. has been put in solitary confinement to stop him being attacked by other lags behind bars.German Interior Minister of Schleswig-Holstein, Claus Christian Claussen revealed yesterday the suspect was in a single cell for his own safety at JVA Kiel prison.Mr Claussen said in a statement: #CB, who is a suspect in the Madeleine McCann case, has moved into solitary confinement.#We want to prevent him being attacked by other prisoners in Kiel Prison. #He will only be allowed out of the cell accompanied by guards.#He will be kept in the solitary confinement cell until further notice. The solitary confinement cells are in a separate wing of the prison.#POLICE are quizzing residents of a hamlet where Christian B fled days after Madeleine McCanns disappearance.The Irish Sun revealed last week Christian B had lodged with a British couple and got a job at a restaurant in Foral, km from where Madeleine was snatched.He also spent time living with pals in a foster home there.Police were not aware he went to the village and have never investigated there. But cops thought to be from Portugal have now spoken to workers at a snack bar the rapist frequented in . One local said: #They asked questions about Christian B and were looking for statements from people who knew him.#COMPUTER data is among evidence cops are sting as they continue to investigate Christian B.But so far it is #not strong enough#to charge the suspect and bring him to court, Chief Prosecutor Hans Christian Wolters said.He has appealed for #witnesses, video and photos# to complete the puzzle# in the Madeleine McCann investigation.Mr Wolters said: “The issue is the evidence is not strong enough that we can bring him to court but I can tell you it is more than just a suspicion.“We are looking at all sorts of evidence including computer data but to protect the investigation I cannot tell you what it is.#LEAD prosecutor Hans Christian Wolters has told The Sun the investigation into Madeleine McCanns disappearance could last # years#necessary.Speaking yesterday, Mr Wolters said: “We have had hundreds of tips and so have the British police and we are working through them but it takes time to analyse them all.“I am hopeful that we will get that breakthrough piece of information that will help us bring a charge and who knows, maybe it will come from a reader of The Sun.“We carry this on for as long as necessary, evenit takes  years.#Read the full story here.TWISTED Christian B broke into his British ex’s flat sparking chilling echoes of the Madeleine McCann case, according to reports.The convicted sex fiend was so insanely jealous he hid under the woman’s bed in case she brought another man home.His ex, from Berkshire, moved to the Algarve town of Lagos in late  and worked at the Taberna de Lagos restaurant alongside waiter Christian B, who was two years younger.The -year-old barmaid # who has asked not to be identied # came home alone and was horried when he appeared under her bed before coolly walking away.Recalling the incident, she told the Daily Mirror: #I peeked under and got the shock of my le. He was hiding under there, lying on his back, staring at me.#GERMAN prosecutors investigating the prime suspect in the Madeleine McCann case today called on Sun readers to turn detective and solve the mystery.Hans Wolters is convinced rapist Christian B, , is responsible for her murder but is desperate for help from Brits who may hold the key to cracking the crime.Mr Wolters said: “We need the help of the readers of The Sun. Maybe there are some British tourists who spent their time between  and  in Portugal, in Praia da Luz, and took some video or pictures.“I hope there are some readers of The Sun who can help us to find the murderer of Madeleine McCann.#CHRISTIAN B had a #hair trigger temper# and threatened a pal with a kne, a German documentary revealed last night.Former pal Norbert M spoke of the -year-olds temper on the RTL two-hour special.He said: #In , I took over a kiosk that had previously been run by him.“He wanted to take a freezer and the air conditioning with him, even though they didnt belong to him. He was very aggressive.A FRIEND of Christian B last year told a Portuguese court he broke into properties near the McCanns holiday flat in Praia da Luz, The Times reports.Cops say his mobile telephone was used near to where Madeleine vanished about an hour earlier.The-year-old pal was giving evidence at Christian Bs trial in December, wher he wasconvicted of raping a -year-old woman n Praia da Luz in .At Christian Bs home, the friend saw three piles of passports he told him he had stolen during #night walks#.After he was arrested, Christian B had asked his friend to take items from his farmhouse.There, he#noticed some self-burned CDs with labels about certain sexual practices#.CHRISTIAN Bs lawyer, Jan Christian Hochmann, has resigned from the case.But he has not said why he has quit.The -year-old suspect has appointed Johann Schwenn from Hamburg, one of Germanys top lawyers, to represent him.Friedrich Fülscher, who is also representing Christian B, told RTL yesterday: #Christian B is not making any statements on the case at the moment.#We ask for your understanding that we as defence attorneys are not making any statements either.#THE German prosecutor leading the Madeleine McCann investigation has appeared to criticise Portuguese officials handling the case.Hans Christian Wolters said relations with the Portuguese were#more cumbersome# than those with the Met.He said: #Working together with the authorities in south European countries is generally more time-consuming.#They take a long time for everything.#PORTUGUESE officials think Madeleine McCanns parents are #responsible for her disappearance# the German prosecutor leading the investigation believes.Hans Christian Wolters said: #From our perspective, the suspect is in jail in Germany right now. And this is not the case for Maddies parents. #We think that the parents dont have anything to do with it. #We are convinced that our -year-old suspect is the murderer of Maddie McCann.#A PIECE of blue material held of a Portuguese forensic lab could provide the vital link between Christian B and Madeleine. The material comes from the bedspread draped over the bed the three-year-old was sleeping on when she was abducted.Tests recovered an incomplete DNA profile from a speck of saliva. Police hope advances in DNA testing may provide a full profile for comparison with the suspects. Thats all from us today, but heres a wrap up of the main stories of the day.Madeleine McCann cops yesterday probed newly unearthed satellite pictures of prime suspect Christian Bs campervan days after she vanished.A Spanish investigator has spent days scouring old satellite imagery after the -year-old serial child sex beast was identied last week.And German police and Scotland Yard have now been sent a picture which could show the roof of the VW Westfalia T van parked near his former Praia da Luz home.The image could prove crucial because it suggests the distinctive van was taken back to open land Christian B was familiar with after living close-by for six years.But it raises questions over why Christian B ed to the farmhouse just days after Madeleine vanished when he was living in the campervan, not the run-down home.Imagery shows the white roof of a van of similar dimensions to the VW parked beside a hedge yards from a ramshackle single-storey former farmhouse plot.He lived there with a German lover from  to , when he did a runner and left the building strewn with debris including wigs and smashed computer gear.Full story here.Christian Bs British ex has given details of their relationship, which she described as #very nice#.The Daily Mirror reports that they had become friends in the Spring of , with the woman describing him as #very charming#.But Christian B also reportedly beat her during their fling # which lasted less than a year # slamming her head against a wall in the ladies toilets of bar where she worked.The petite barmaid incredibly forgave Christian B after her New Year’s Day beating # but dumped him in mid- when she found women’s underwear in his bag.Prime suspect Christian B broke into his British ex’s flat sparking chilling echoes of the Madeleine McCann case, according to reports.The convicted sex fiend was so insanely jealous he hid under the woman’s bed in case she brought another man home.His ex, from Berkshire, moved to the Algarve town of Lagos in late  and worked at the Taberna de Lagos restaurant alongside waiter Christian B, who was two years younger.The -year-old barmaid # who has asked not to be identied # came home alone and was horried when he appeared under her bed before coolly walking away.She was left traumatised by the incident, three years before three-year-old Maddie was snatched from her holiday home in Praia da Luz on Portugal’s Algarve.Recalling the incident, she told the Daily Mirror: #I peeked under and got the shock of my le. He was hiding under there, lying on his back, staring at me.“He got out from under the bed, acted like everything was normal, said goodbye to me, walked out and closed the door behind him.“I was there all alone, just shaking and shaking.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: eastenders new tarzan speak was for the hard of thinking
story: THESE last three months, it’s seemed like only two places on Earth have avoided being trapped in lockdown.Sweden and EastEnders.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesAnd I don’t know what state of paranoid despair the Scandinavians have been enduring but I would still take my chances pub crawling in downtown Malmo before I set foot in Walford, where the only acknowledgement of the coronavirus outbreak has been a practical one.To drag out the torture, it’s now only on twice a week. A delaying-the-inevitable tactic which meant, by the time Phil and Dennis’s tickets for the April  game between West Ham and Burnley arrived in mid May, the fixture was as dead as Dennis.A lucky escapeyou ask me.The day of reckoning, when it runs out of episodes, fast approaches, of course. For the duration of the outbreak, though, it’s been a biological miracle.Regulars have packed The Vic, mobbed the Bridge Street market and just stood around gawping and muttering, in their usual community-serving way, when Keegan’s sandwich van was trashed by the local drug dealers.The presence of a global pandemic hasn’t stopped EastEnders lecturing us about other medical issues, obviously.Since the boat party accident, in February, it’s been particularly concerned about Ben Mitchell’s deafness, which cut no ice with me for a couple of good reasons.Firstly, Ben Mitchell is a dreadful, immoral, six-headed little turd who it’s impossible to like, let alone love.Secondly, they’d forgotten he was partially deaf for most of the previous decade.There’s not an international crisis or continuity glitch in the universe that can stand in the way of EastEnders’ moral grandstanding, though, so they decided viewers should “see and hear” last week’s heist episode, with Barry Grant off Brookside, through the eyes and ears of Ben.A particularly gormless enterprise, this one, which went off like Norman Collier and Jimi Hendrix on the same bill at The Half Moon in Putney, and was all feedback and missing words.To ram home the message for the hard of thinking, the action was also accompanied by word cloud subtitles that appeared to have been written by Tarzan.“Keep mind on job.”“Cut power.”“Ben, this mistake.”“Daughter without father.”Compared with other EastEnders episodes, I enjoyed it a lot. I usually do when the show tries something a bit dferent and thought you could actually write the entire history of the show in half a dozen lines of this new Tarzan-speak.“Den hate Angie.” “Peter change head.” “Phil. Him shot.” “You not mother.” “Me am mother.” “Peter change head again.” “Get out pub.” It’d be timely as well. After  years and four months of almost constant shouting and stall-minding, EastEnders goes off air next week.Tantalisingly, The Sun’s very own Andy Halls reported, on Friday, that when it s the show will have dropped its old storylines. A dream scenario which allowed me to fantasise about EastEnders .. A happier, funnier show that’s only on twice a week, where the BBC doesn’t endlessly bask in its own right-on virtue and the majority of characters actually sound like Londoners, instead of stage-schooleditorials.But that’s not going to happen, is it So I’m just going to enjoy the silence. Tarzan like.TIPPING Point, Ben Shephard: “Which city in the Midlands shares its name with a meeting between two sporting rivals ”Bill: “Birmingham.”Celebrity Mastermind, John Humphrys: “In an th century poem, what season of the year did Keats describe as ‘a season of mists and mellow fruitfulness’ ”Monty Panesar: “Oliver Twist.”Ben Shephard: “The Anglo-Dutch wars were fought primarily between England and which modern-day country ”Amy: “Denmark.”.THE Last Leg, Desiree Burch on the George Floyd fallout: “Follow black artists and thinkers on social media, people who have good resources, information, opinions and insights. Right now I have two shows you could watch — Desiree’s Coming Early and Tar Baby.”Or you could watch Too Hot To Handle, where Netflix films young people having sex while artist thinker Desiree offers her “insights and opinions”.But she’s clearly too modest to mention her role on that one.THIS week’s winner is Tory MP Andrew Bridgen and Harry Enfield’s Tim Nice But Dim. Sent in by RJ.FIRST job for the Beeb’s new Director General, Tim Davie  Find out how Peter Crouch: Save Our Summer ended up on primetime, Saturday night, BBC. Seriously, how  It’s a late-night ITV show, with no one to bleep out the swearing, but with BBC levels of over-manning.The star, obviously, was Peter Crouch, who’s actually funnier than  per cent of TV comedians and more likable than all of them, but not yet ready to front his own show. So they added Maya Jama, who looked sensational in her Status Quo Blue For You-era denims, the compulsory Horne Section and Chris Ramsey, who was hiding behind a fence at the start. And should’ve stayed there. All deserve our sympathy. SOS was meant to be a Euro  spin-off and when the tournament vanished so did the show’s point. Camera angles also seem to have gone to hell, but that’s maybe an act of socially distanced mercy given what’s happening front and centre.Saturday’s content included: A teabag- flipping contest between Mo Farah and Ellie Simmonds, parachuting with Jermaine Jenas, which was straight off the Alan Partridge script and foul-mouthed football “bantz” from Rio Ferdinand, who said his career was ended by Peter Crouch, so may have been playing keepy-uppy to the Match Of The Day theme tune as some sort of twisted payback.The really alarming thing, though, is the series lasts eight weeks.Save Our Summer  At this rate, there’ll be a dark cloud hanging over autumn as well.For the record, it was the BBC News.SPRINGWATCH’s Steve Backshall wearing a “No planet B” T-shirt like he’s a -year-old student, rather than a -year-old BBC presenter who won’t shut up about his three kids. Bafta giving nominations to The Greatest Dancer and The Ranganation but not a Best Drama nod to Line Of Duty.This Morning’s Phillip Schofield losing his very short temper with John Torode over yoghurt dressing. Anyone who says “chowing down” instead of eating. And the clearly smitten GMB host Susanna Reid making an involuntary groping gesturewith her left hand, just after she says the name Keir Starmer. Easy tiger.PETER Crouch: “It wasn’t all about improving, it was also about getting better.”Ian Wright: “The one thing about Gerrard was his professionalism and the fact he was so versatile.”Paul Merson: “It was definitely half an open goal.”                                 SKY Documentaries’ McMillion, the best show on TV.Ralph’s wedding on The A Word. ITV’s th birthday tribute to the great Bradley Walsh.The GMB spat between Piers Morgan and Donald Trump’s lawyer, Rudy Giuliani, which had everything except the obvious reprimand: “Rudy. Stop your messin’ around.”And Channel ’s Murder In The Outback, where disgraced Australian lawyer Andrew Fraser proves, beyond much forensic doubt, Bradley Murdoch did indeed kill Peter Falconio.The only slight glitch being, he’s trying to prove the exact opposite.Watch it, Channel , tonight and tomorrow, pm. The self-delusion becomes hypnotic. A Gillian Burke on Springwatch B Connell Waldron on Normal People C Comedian Tom Allen on nearly everything MOST surprising thing about Britain’s Best Parent  Anita Rani isn’t the most annoying person on this Channel  show.In fact, she’s not even close to a medal position thanks to the other five – two couples and a single mum – who must champion their own style of parenting, whether  it’s “pushy” or “vegan” or mollycoddling or just sort of lying around in bed all day treating their offspring as the hired help.Like the rest of us, Channel  silently understands, of course, listening to strangers talk about their small children is no more engaging or enlightening than listening to a ­scientologist talk about L. Ron Hubbard, so they’ve included a few eccentrics to liven  up the process.On the one hand there’s martial arts enthusiast Robin, who explains: “Our parenting style is influenced by eastern philosophy. Buddhism, Taoism, Confucianism,” ventriloquism, egotism, Roxette’s fourth album Tourism.On the other there’s gender fluid feminist nut Joana, who is attempting to bring up five-year-old son Willow as “a free spirit”, by banning the word “boy”, refusing to buy him “militaristic toys” and plastering her house in idiotic Socialist Worker propaganda.Hopefully, little Willow will be a stalwart of his local golf club and TA unit  in about  years’ time.But that’s no real saving grace for the show, nor a reason to watch any part of Britain’s Best Parent, apart from the final vote where, every week, the studio audience has to choose between those “free spirits” who let the kids rule the roost and those couples, like David and Nicky, who run their house more like an SAS boot camp.And every week, I’m happy to report, they vote for the boot camp.All hope for Britain may not be lost.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: family woes the queen let go of reigns
story: Unencumbered by a relentless schedule of pressing the flesh around the country, she’s having the first extended break of her admirably dutul le.A rare sighting of her on horseback shows her deep in thought, perhaps reflecting, as we all do in moments of quiet contemplation, on the well- being of her loved ones. In her case, it’s not pretty.Where to start  How about son number two who, thanks to his friendship with billionaire paedophile Jeffrey Epstein is now embroiled in an ugly, cross-Atlantic ding dong with an American legal system that kowtows to no one.Clearly, Andrew hoped his royal status might ensure discretion. But the US Department of Justice has other ideas and has now publicly accused him of lying when he says he has offered to co-operate with their inquiries into Epstein’s questionable activities.It’s uncertain whether The Queen and Prince Philip have Netflix in their lockdown lair at Windsor Castle, butthey have watched the documentary Jeffrey Epstein: Filthy Rich — in which their reportedly favourite son is mentioned many times — they will have spat out their popcorn.Aside from the well- documented claim by Virginia Roberts that she was trafficked to London at the age of  to have sex with Prince Andrew , one of the most damning accusations is the alleged sighting of him at Epstein’s private island where airport staff now say that the billionaire, who allegedly killed himself last year, frequently arrived with “underage girls”.Ordinary people staying schtum at the time for fear of losing their jobs is one thing but the silence of the many powerful men who enjoyed Epstein’s hospitality is quite another.Prince Andrew is undoubtedly one of them and, at the very least, he owes it to Epstein’s survivors to sit down with the US Department of Justice and reveal what he does, or doesn’t, know.And asthat’s not enough to give his mother sleepless nights, he and his ex-we Sarah Ferguson are also being sued for a £.million unpaid debt on a Swiss ski chalet.Meanwhile, son number oneis happy enough in his second marriage, but reportedly harbouring a deep sadness that one of his sons has chosen to leg it to the US, along with the baby grandson he can no longer hug.On top of that, he faces forking out millions to help Harry and Meghan pay for personal protection because not only have they chosen to settle down in paparazzi central, but in a country where the gun culture means any nutter can wander into a store and arm up as easily as buying a microwave.Son number threehas just announced that his children won’t use royal titles and will work for a living.But one wonders whether, given the pressure to streamline the monarchy, they jumped before they were pushed.Daughter Anne is a reliable stalwart, but grandson Peter recently announced his marriage to we Autumn is over, and as for grandsons William and Harry, it’s fair to say that the reported fall-out of those two young brothers who walked so stoically behind their mother’s coffin must be causing The Queen great sadness.So, with all that going on with her nearest and dearest, how will she feel when lockdown finally lts and she’s expected to put on a brave face to the world again Will she think, “I’ve had enough” and, as was rumoured prior to the pandemic, abdicate on her th birthday next year Doubtful, given that she pledged she would be of service “my whole le” and that, traditionally, British monarchs occupy the throne until death.But, given her family ructions, who could blame hershe did decide to call it a day If he had bodyguards with him on his ious visits to Epstein, then perhaps they could enlighten the US authorities on Andrew’s movements at the time Andhe didn’t, then why the hell does he need them now Asthe new, -day quarantine rule wasn’t daft enough, it’s emerged that police have been told to take “no immediate action”a passenger gives a  address on arrival in the UK.Right. So the only travellers affected by this ludicrous policy will be the law-abiding and public figures who risk being spotted on holiday then named and shamedthey don’t self-isolate upon .Everyone  can just give their details as Mickey Mouse of Taking The Mickey Street, and go about their le with impunity.Meanwhile, the airline industry is teetering on the verge of bankruptcy because it sends out the message that Britain is closed.Well. Done. Everyone.Prince Albert of Monaco has a problem – his subjects are getting too old.According to the BBC documentary Inside Monaco, it’s the most elderly country on Earth.So the principality has launched an “influencer” award aimed at attracting a younger “YouTube” generation who,the footage of their garish supercars is anything to go by, have money but zero taste.The awards are the brainchild of the prince’s friend . . .  . . .  Princess Camilla of Bourbon Two Sicilies, Duchess of Castro If Little Britain ever doesto our screens, she’s a shoo-in.Dancing On Ice is reportedly considering filming the show with two-metre social-distancing measures in place.If the rumours of their big fallout are true, last series contestant Caprice and her dance partner Hamish Gaman would have had no trouble with implementing it.Pixar’s animated movie Coco has been voted the most tear-jerking film of all time, with Marley  Me in second place and Schindler’s List in third.It was the result of a Twitter survey by US film critic Kevin Lee, who asked followers to tell him “the hardest you’ve ever cried in a movie TV show”.I haven’t seen Coco, but my weepiest, cinematic experience didn’t make the top ten.It’s Mask – starring Cher and Eric Stolz – a film that rendered me so inconsolable that the man in front of me askedI could “shut the hell up”.And Goodbye Mr Chips wasn’t far behind either – but at least I was home on the sofa for that one.Other than Leonardo DiCaprio browsing for a new girlfriend, who actually shops at underwear store Victoria’s Secret any more Not many Brits, it seems – its  UK stores have just gone in to administration.Back in the day, VS underwear was tasteful and good quality, but somewhere along the way it lost sight of its core customer.The owners clearly forgot that, while men lusted after the scantily-clad “Angels” such as Alessandra Ambrosio at its catwalk shows , it’s primarily women who buy lingerie.And the majority want “tastefully boudoir” not “garishly bordello”.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
