title: lockdown workers skiving two hours without boss noticing
story: A quarter of employees say working from home means they can get away with doing less without getting caught.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMost Brits work an average of . hours a week - but many are now doing much less.A poll revealed people working from home due to coronavirus have been doing two hours and  minutes less each day - or  hours and  minutes a week.Three in  blame the pandemic for making them less productive.The survey found lockdown has meant a  per cent drop in productivity - equivalent to almost two days less work each week.And it is the stress of working from home that has seen people try to cut down their hours.Many admitted they can now get away with working less each day - and their managers dont notice. The survey, by Mind Gym and Censuswide, also revealed that more than a third of workers have seen a decline in their mental health since being locked down.Feeling isolated and anxious, as well as being away from colleagues and authority, is making people burn out. With almost half the UK workforce working from home, the company has warned this could have “catastrophic” consequences.Mind Gym chief executive Octavius Black said: “Given the anxiety from lockdown and the ineffectiveness of managers in this new environment, masses of UK workers are likely either to opt-out or burnout.“The impact on the UK’s productivity would be catastrophic.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: junk food chains share blame severity coroanvirus pandemic
story: Experts have urged the government to push the food industry to introduce restrictions on the promotion of unhealthy foods.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt comes as ious studies revealed that people with obesity were at a higher risk of dying from the coronavirus.While other experts urged the government to consider weight loss surgery as a solution to the pandemic.So far in the UK, Covid- has killed over , people and experts have said the government must “seize this opportunity”.In an editorial published in the British Medical Journal, co-author of the study and professor of cardiovascular medicine at Barts and The London Hospital, Graham MacGregor said restrictions could reduce fatalities. Unlike most other risk factors identied for Covid- such as age, sex and ethnicity - obesity is a modiable risk factor.This is why governments worldwide must seize the opportunity to help people to eat more healthily and enforce measures to restrict the promotion, marketing, and advertising of unhealthy foods and ensure their reformulation to contain far less salt, sugar and saturated fat.This would reduce mortality from this vicious virus and many other chronic diseases.The researchers also noted that  per cent of confirmed Covid infections in the UK were made up of people who were overweight.This is while  per cent of deaths in hospitals were also from people who were overweight.Obesity can lead to a number of other serious conditions such as high blood pressure, type  diabetes, heart disease, stroke and cancer.As the virus started to creep into the UK in March and rumours of a lockdown started to circulate, many people started to panic buy.This left shelves in supermarkets across the country empty.Researchers said that this, combined with an increase in food poverty limited the access people had to fresh foods.“This tilts the balance towards a greater consumption of highly processed foods and those with long shelf lives that are usually high in salt, sugar, and saturated fat.The authors claimed the food industry was given a huge free marketing opportunity by the pandemic.They added that the government has “done little” to combat obesity across the country, despite a sugar tax having been introduced.The researchers wrote: Reducing salt, sugar, and saturated fat across the board would improve the diet of the entire population and bring even greater benefits for people who are most socially deprived.The toll of morbidity and mortality from Covid- has made this more apparent and more urgent than ever.The Food and Drink Federationsaid Prof MacGregor’s views on the food industry are well known.Chief operating officer Tim Rycroft said: To blame the food industry for the Covid- mortality rate is deeply offensive. Millions of key workers across the supply chain have continued to work throughout this pandemic and are hidden heroes, keeping Britain fed.He added that manufacturers are fully engaged with a wide range of government-led initiatives designed to tackle the huge public health challenge of obesity.  FDF members’ voluntary work is already delivering substantial changes. title: steve chalke get kids back to school
story: An incredible army of ­volunteers responded to the call.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesNow we need to do the same for our schools.Classrooms have a vital role to play in child development — especially for vulnerable ­children. So we need a strategy. We need leadership, and we need an army of recruits.First, let’s not waste those upcoming summer weeks. There is no need for school to be out for summer.As the Children’s Commissioner Anne Longfield has said, " rel"noreferrer noopener"our schools should be open in some form or other over the six-week summer holidays. We can’t afford to leave it all to the autumn and hope for the best.I am not trying to trap the wonderful teachers into another six weeks without a break. They have already been ­working flat out over the past three months, developing home- learning resources.I understand the practical as well as contractual concerns that need to be negotiated.But without overburdening, or ­risking anyone’s health — where there’s a will, there’s a way.There are teaching staff, ex-teaching staff, retired teaching staff and countless volunteers who I believe are ready and willing to step up and help supervise children under the leadership of professionals.Second, we need to think ­creatively about space.I am the leader of a group of  schools around the country." rel"noreferrer noopener"There is just not enough space in any of our school buildings to properly social- ­distance and house all pupils at the same time.We are not alone here.So let’s use other empty buildings — village halls, town halls, hotel conference halls, church halls and closed museums. What great learning opportunities for “bubbles” — those small groups in which all children are taught now.Third, this moment gives us the opportunity to rethink what education is. If it’s true that we are community beings — that we learn in community from one another — then we need to rethink the curriculum.Education has always been about more than maths, English and geography.It is every little bit as much about social and emotional development.Human beings are social beings. We thrive when we are connected and struggle when we’re not. I talked to a GP who lives up our street and is the mother of an ­intelligent six-year-old boy. She told me last week about how concerned she is about him “becoming withdrawn”. She is right to be worried.We have to get used to the fact that “remote” learning will probably be part of the ­equation for the foreseeable future. So, once again, let’s think dferently.Let’s use the days when children are in school with us dferently to the days when they are at home.Leave the academic subjects for days when they can work at home on projects we have set them the day before. title: sir geoff palmer keep satues evidence
story: If you remove the evidence you remove the deed.These statues are our history — for both black and white people — so removing them is tampering with the past.Slave traders Edward Colston and Robert Milligan, whose statues have been torn down, are part of black history, which is part of British history.I was born in Jamaica and came to Britain aged  in .People have tried to exclude me but Jamaica has been part of the British story since .I object to the fact that someone would say I’ve got no British connections.I’ve had a long career in academia specialising in the science of brewing and in  became the first black professor in Scotland.I’ve achieved six doctorates and been knighted.Today I’m Jamaica’s Honorary Consul in Scotland.I’m an example of what can be achieved with good people around you and a bit of luck.But I don’t think people’s lives should be dependent on luck.We have prejudices in society that limit representation, education and opportunities for black people.Last year I arrived in Edinburgh to give a lecture and the attendant at the door said: “What do you want ”I said: “l’ve come to give a lecture.” She replied: “When ”I said: “pm.’ She said: “You can’t be because the lecture then is being given by Professor Sir Geoff Palmer.”She’d never seen black people with any status. title: michael schumacher stem cell operation
story: French cardiologist Dr Philippe Menasche, who is known to have operated on the Formula One racing legend, , before, will perform a pioneering heart op on the German, Italian media reports.French newspaper Le Dauphine reports the latest procedure could take place in the next few days.In , Schumacher suffered a head injury when skiing off-piste in the resort of Meribel in the French Alps.However, his condition has been shrouded in secrecy as he is treated privately by a team of doctors at his home in Geneva, Switzerland.Yet, according to Dr Nicola Acciari, a top neurosurgeon, Schumacher is suffering from osteoporosis and muscle atrophy caused by his lack of movement since his accident.He said: The goal is to regenerate Michaels nervous system.Dr Menasche, who is known as a “pioneer in stem cell surgery”, is reportedly going to carry out another stem cell op on the racing drivers heart.But, the exact details of the procedure are unknown and the Frenchmans techniques have been called mysterious.According to Spanish outlet minutos, Menasche is using surgery to transfer stem cells from the Germans heart to his brain. In stem cell therapy, cells are taken from either bone marrow or the patients own heart and injected into other parts of the body in order to repair damaged tissue.Schumacher, who won a record seven F world championships with Benetton and Ferrari, underwent his first stem-cell therapy in Paris in September last year.French journalist Jean-Michel Décugis told The Times that the stem cell therapy will have an anti-inflammatory effect which will mostly likely impact the brain. He said: Our sources say that Michael Schumacher is receiving stem cell perfusions that... produce a systemic anti-inflammatory effect.That is to say they reach the whole body and you could imagine that they reach Michael Schumachers brain.Its quite mysterious. Officially [Menasché] works only on the heart.Stem cell therapy - also known as regenerative medicine - promotes the repair of diseased, injured and dysal tissues.Stem cells are the bodys raw materials - the cells from which all specialised cells, like brain or heart cells, are generated.Under lab conditions stem cells can ide to create daughter cells.These daughter cells can form new specialised cells with a specic- brain, heart muscle, blood or bone cells.The pioneering treatment is still relatively new and many studies are examining its potential.In Michael Schumachers case its understood doctors are aiming to use the treatment to regenerate his nervous system, which includes the brain and spinal cord.It could involve scientists taking stem cells from the Formula One legends bone marrow, to create new brain and spinal cord cells with an aim of treating those that were injured in his accidentHe is carrying out experiments with [secretome] that is made by a laboratory from new stem cells and injected into veins, until now only on animals.Mr Décugis also claims that Schumacher is being injected with secretome -protein found in the human body - which he says Menasche calls stem cell juice.In October, Menasche warned fans that he does not work miracles following the first widely-reported stem cell therapy on the sports star.He also slammed claims he was carrying out experiments on the legendary racing driver.Speaking with Italian newspaper La Republica, he said: I do not perform miracles.My team and I are not doing an experiment, an abominable term that is not in line with a serious medical view.And after the procedure last year, a nurse told Le Parisien that Schumacher was conscious.She said: Yes he is in my service ... And I can assure you that he is conscious.Speaking about the cutting-edge procedure, Acciari said: Over the past  years, science has made enormous progress with stem cell treatment.But that does not change that we still do not know much about the human brain.We are not able to say what the results will be.In January, Italian brain surgeon Nicola Acciari - who has not reportedly treated the German - claims he will still be changed from the man his millions of fans remember.We must imagine a person very dferent from the one we remember on the track, with a very altered and deteriorated organic, muscular and skeletal structure, said Acciari.All as a result of the brain trauma he suffered, he told Italian newspaper Contro Copertina.Last month, former Ferrari driver Felipe Massa said he is very close to Schumacher and said his situation is not easy.He told Fox Brazil: I know how heis, I have information. My relationship with him has always been very close.It is less close with his we Corinna because she did not go to many races. But I think the main thing about all this is that we know that his situation is not easy. title: mandela imperialists statue oxford head
story: Thousands have demanded the universitys Cecil Rhodesmonument be removed as protestors chanted take it down during the citys Black Lives Matter protest on Tuesday evening. But vice-chancellor Professor Louise Richardson insisted Mandela, who teamed up with a trust founded by Rhodes before his death in , would not have sought simplistic solutions to complex problems.She told The : I think he was a man of deep nuance who recognised complex problems for what they were. And I dont think he sought simplistic solutions to complex problems.The question is, how do we judge people  How do you judge Cecil Rhodes  Do we judge him by our values today or do we judge him by the context of his time I grew up in Ireland where Oliver Cromwell to me was what Voldemort [the Harry Potter villain] is to my children. And yet a statue of Cromwell stands outside Westminster. Does that mean it should be taken down  No.This is the stuff of academia. This is the stuff of universities. This is what education is all about. I dont think we can pretend our history is dferent from what it was.It follows slave trader Edward Colstons statue being toppled at Bristols Black Lives Matter protest on Sunday, raising fears that others including Winston Churchills Parliament Square monument will face the same fate.Protestors pulled Colstons statue down with rope before rolling it into the harbour while London demonstrators defaced Winston Churchills statue accusing him of being a racist.In  the South African statesman Mandela told Westminster Hall he would team up with a trust founded by Rhodes in order to build a better future for Africans.Rhodes was one of the th centurys most famous imperialists, helping colonise much of Southern Africa and having Rhodesia - now Zimbabwe - and Gambia named after him.As Prime Minister of the Cape Colony from  to , his government restricted the rights of black Africans by setting financial qualications for voting.Rhodes was a student at Oriel, created Rhodes scholarships and gave money to the College.He has now been accused of being racist and a British supremacist with growing calls for institutions to distance themselves from his legacy.In his last testament he said: I contend that we [the English] are the first race in the world, and that the more of the world we inhabit the better it is for the human race. I contend that every acre added to our territory means the birth of more of the English race who otherwise would not be brought into existence.He referred to other parts of the world as inhabiting the most despicable specimens of human beings.The Rhodes Must Fall campaign ignited in  at the University of Cape Town and soon won momentum from Oxford students demanding the fall the imperialist above the Oriel College entrance.He died from heart failure in , aged , at his seaside cottage in Muizenberg.In this, I am certain, Cecil John Rhodes and I would have made common cause, he said.Professor Richardson added: Those speeches by Mandela were extraordinary in their generosity. He said that we have to acknowledge our past but focus on the future.Hiding our history is not the route to enlightenment. We have to understand our history and we have to confront our history.Oxfords chancellor Lord Patten said he had been present when Mandela signed the agreement to set up the Mandela Rhodes Foundation. He claimed Mandela said: Cecil Rhodes, you and I are going to have to work together now.Lord Patten told the BBC: For me there is a bit of hypocrisy in Oxford taking money for  scholars a year, about a fth of them from Africa, to come to Oxford, and then saying we want to throw the Rhodes statue in the Thames.For all the problems associated with Cecil Rhodes history,it was alright for Mandela then I have to say its pretty well alright with me.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus facemasks prevent hay fever pollen explosion
story: Hay fever symptoms have been on the rise this year due to a “pollen explosion” caused by an unusually sunny spring that meant pollen was released earlier than usual.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesSpeaking on This Morning yesterday, Dr Glenis Scadding, a consultant physician in allergy and rhinology, said sufferers may be able to beat the symptomsthey wear a face covering.Wearing a face mask or covering will soon be compulsory on public transport and hosts Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield asked Dr Glenis whether or not these could help with hay fever.Responding she said: Yes. Wearing a mask helps to reduce pollen coming into your mouth and nose, which is great.“Adding a pair of wrap around spectacles will keep it out of your eyes.”The pollen forecast ies depending on what part of the country you are in and today the south of the county will be hit by high pollen levels.This week experts warned that pollen would flourish over the next few days.This is while the midlands and north west will have mild pollen and the north and Scotland will have low levels.Dr Glenis added that some areas of the country do have it worse than others.“The south gets the pollen first because the climate is warmer and then the pollen gradually moves northwards so that the far north of Scotland is probably about three weeks behind having its main pollen count.She also said that when the pollen count is high it could trigger first time outbreaks.“There may be people who have not previously been sensitive enough to notice hay fever who will get it this year.”. Use vaselineDabbing a little bit of petroleum jelly around the edges of your nose works as a barrier to trap pollen before you breathe it in.A standard tin of Vaseline will do the trick – just smear a small amount around the edge of your nostrils.. Try some nasal sprayIf you’re struggling with a blocked, itchy or runny nose, a steroid nasal spray might provide you with some extra relief.They work by reducing the inflammation inside the nose.It’s best to try and use them for a week or two before you think your symptoms will start as they can take a few days to work, according to NHS advice.. Shower morePollen can stick around for a while on your skin even after youve gone back indoors.If you have been out in the sun all day then its important to make sure you shower afterwards, this will wash away any of the pollen still attached to your skin and hair.. Cut down on boozeBeer, wine and other spirits all contain histamine - the chemical that sets off allergy symptoms in the body.Sick of fighting against runny eyes  The Met Office recommends sticking to the soft stuff where possible to avoid adding any unnecessary allergy pressure.. Take your meds at the right timeIt may seem obvious for anyone that an antihistamine will help, but its actually knowing when to take them that could make the dference.As well as wearing a mask to help stop symptoms, she added that people who follow a plant-based diet may not experience severe symptoms.Diet is fascinating because diet alters the bacteria living in your gut, and they in turn could alter the way your body reacts immunologically.A diet that is rich in short chain fatty acids promotes good bacteria, and the sorts of things that help that are plant-based foods - fruits, vegetables, and also yogurt and fish.This year the country has seen a clear strain of hay fever related symptoms and Google searches have revealed that more and more people are looking for ways to treat them.Earlier this month money revealed that searches related to hay fever relief wipes had increased by over , per cent during a seven day period at the end of May.Between May  and June , searches for the “best hay fever relief” were up by  per cent.This is while searches for “how to stop hay fever” were up by  per cent.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: woman makes home unsellable after 30 years decorating and youll see why
story: Mary Rose Young, , has been painting her home in Lydney, Gloucestershire in bright colours by hand since .She bought the two cottages - once lived in by squatters - for just £,, and after years of pain-staking renovations she decided to sellin .Real estate agents told her the home should be worth at least £,, but its eccentric style meant it has failed to drum up any serious interest.Only one curious person was persuaded to view the house and they chose not to buy.Ms Young hoped to sell the home to open up a boutique bed and breakfast nearby.The cottage is full of vivid colours, including striking yellow and green walls, black and white tiled floors, a zebra-patterned toilet seat and bright pink furnishings - the same colour as Ms Youngs hair.She shares the house with her musician husband, Phil Butcher, .Despite a lack of buying interest Ms Young refuses to change the style of her home.“I love my house and the house really works for me. I’m a colourful person and I even have pink hair. I like it more and more as I get older, she said.“I made this house around my own le and I wasn’t thinking about it being sellable.“We’re living like two children in a doll’s house and in retrospect why would anybody  want to buy it “I just thought it might go to a mad collector of my work who might want to buy it, but no one was interested.Ms Young said she enjoyed transforming the property from two rundown cottages into a colourful playhouse for adults. “It became a really fun project for me on the side of my pottery business and I was so galvanised by it I ended up neglecting my pottery at times.“I painted it all myself and I would get help for some bitsI was in a hurry and was trying to work on the pottery. When you do it by yourself, you do it with all your heart.“I’ve stopped noticing how colourful it is because I’ve lived here for so long.“Lots of people are self-conscious and don’t say much when they see the decoration, but the right reaction is to laugh and go ‘oh wow.’“It should make you feel like a child walking into a sweet shop. I want people to feel like adults can have lots of fun too.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus mutating very slowly raising vaccine hopes
story: A vaccine has not yet been developed for the virus but its lack of change will make it easier for those who are trying to create an effective jab.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMolecular biologists have now said that working on vaccines with one strain is “much more straightforward than a virus that is changing quickly”.Peter Thielen from the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Laboratory has been sequencing the viral genome of Covid- to understand its foundations.So far in the UK Covid- has killed over , people and globally it has taken the lives ofover , people.Governments across the globe introduced strict lockdown measures, some of which are now being eased due to a drop in cases. Speaking to Medical Express Professor Winston Timp said: It isnt going to be possible for us to truly be able toto normal until we have a vaccine.”This is while professor Stuart Ray, who is leading the Hopkins viral genomics effort along with Prof Timp said: The low mutation rate of the virus means it should be possible to generate a successful vaccine.”He added that this could boost efforts to develop potential treatments for the disease.Covid- samples examined by researchers have proved to be similar globally and Prof Thielen added that the genetic changes which are occurring are not resulting in dferent strains of the virus.He said this is key, asa vaccine is to be successful then it needs to account for changes and mutations in order to protect people.Normal flu, Prof Thielen says, changes over a short period of time but he said this is the opposite for Covid-.It is changing slowly, and because there is no existing immunity to the virus, it doesnt have any evolutionary pressure to change as it spreads through the population.The lack of change in Covid-, scientists say, means thata vaccine is made there is no reason as to why it would not be effective everywhere.Prof Thielen said a vaccine that blocks Covid’s ability to infect a cell would be highly effective.This, he says, is due to the fact that the virus would not be able to generate an active infection - therefore it would not be able to spread the disease.Viruses replicate copies of cells and use an enzyme called a polymerase.Covid- polymerase has a “proofreading activity”.This means that once a genome is replicated an enzyme can find its mistakes and correct them.The scientists say there have been under  mutations of the Covid samples they are studying from China and said this means a vaccine will work against all of them.With a virus as stable as Covid- the But I think the main thing about all this is that we know that his situation is not easy. He is in a dficult phase but we need to respect him and the family.They do not like to ulge any information, so who am I to do that  Since his accident, Schumachers son Mick has followed in his fathers footsteps and has become a racing driver competing in Formula Two.And Massa said he hopes the Ferrari legend can one day watch his boy compete in the sport he loves.He said: I dream and pray every day that he gets better and that he can appear at a circuit again, especially now that his son is racing.So I pray that it may happen one day.Meanwhile, French newspaper Le Dauphine reports Schumachers latest stem cell procedure could take place in the next few days.Dr Philippe Menasche, who is known as a “pioneer in stem cell surgery”, is reportedly going to carry out another op on the racing drivers heart.But, the exact details of the procedure are unknown and the Frenchmans techniques have been called mysterious.According to Spanish outlet minutos, Menasche is using surgery to transfer stem cells from the Germans heart to his brain. In stem cell therapy, cells are taken from either bone marrow or the patients own heart and injected into other parts of the body in order to repair damaged tissue.Schumacher, who won a record seven F world championships with Benetton and Ferrari, underwent his first stem-cell therapy in Paris in September last year.French journalist Jean-Michel Décugis told The Times that the stem cell therapy will have an anti-inflammatory effect which will mostly likely impact the brain. He said: Our sources say that Michael Schumacher is receiving stem cell perfusions that... produce a systemic anti-inflammatory effect.That is to say they reach the whole body and you could imagine that they reach Michael Schumachers brain.Its quite mysterious. Officially [Menasché] works only on the heart.He is carrying out experiments with [secretome] that is made by a laboratory from new stem cells and injected into veins, until now only on animals.Mr Décugis also claims that Schumacher is being injected with secretome -protein found in the human body - which he says Menasche calls stem cell juice.Stem cell therapy - also known as regenerative medicine - promotes the repair of diseased, injured and dysal tissues.Stem cells are the bodys raw materials - the cells from which all specialised cells, like brain or heart cells, are generated.Under lab conditions stem cells can ide to create daughter cells.These daughter cells can form new specialised cells with a specic- brain, heart muscle, blood or bone cells.The pioneering treatment is still relatively new and many studies are examining its potential.In Michael Schumachers case its understood doctors are aiming to use the treatment to regenerate his nervous system, which includes the brain and spinal cord.It could involve scientists taking stem cells from the Formula One legends bone marrow, to create new brain and spinal cord cells with an aim of treating those that were injured in his accidentIn October, Menasche warned fans that he does not work miracles following the first widely-reported stem cell therapy on the sports star.He also slammed claims he was carrying out experiments on the legendary racing driver.Speaking with Italian newspaper La Republica, he said: I do not perform miracles.My team and I are not doing an experiment, an abominable term that is not in line with a serious medical view.And after the procedure last year, a nurse told Le Parisien that Schumacher was conscious.She said: Yes he is in my service ... And I can assure you that he is conscious.Speaking about the cutting-edge procedure, Acciari said: Over the past  years, science has made enormous progress with stem cell treatment.But that does not change that we still do not know much about the human brain.We are not able to say what the results will be.In January, Italian brain surgeon Nicola Acciari - who has not reportedly treated the German - claims he will still be changed from the man his millions of fans remember.We must imagine a person very dferent from the one we remember on the track, with a very altered and deteriorated organic, muscular and skeletal structure, said Acciari.All as a result of the brain trauma he suffered, he told Italian newspaper Contro Copertina.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus briefing today june 11
story: Boris Johnson took the conference on Wednesday, June , where he detailed two major new rules including the end of the sex ban and the introduction of support bubbles.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesThe daily coronavirus press conference s tonight - Thursday, June .It is expected to take place at around pm.They have been held on a regular basis from  Downing Street since March  - but are no longer held on weekends.Health Secretary Matt Hancock will be leading the press conference this evening.Mr Hancock is a regular at these briefings and will be joined by up to two government medical and scientic advisers.Professor Chris Whitty and Sir Patrick Vallance often join the conferences - having spoken alongside Mr Johnson on Wednesday.Meanwhile, NHS National Medical Director for England, Stephen Powis, and Deputy Chief Medical Officer Dr Jenny Harries have appeared on a number of occasions.The press conference will be shown on BBC One and on " rel"noreferrer noopener"BBC iPlayer.Sky News will also be showing the coronavirus briefing.The conferences normally last around an hour.Prime Minister Boris Johnson revealed a number of new lockdown measures were being eased over the next week.Starting from Saturday, June , single adults - or single parents with children under the age of  - can mix with one other household in what is referred to as support bubbles.This would allow grandparents living alone to visit their grandchildren, where they would be able to stay overnight and dont need to social distance during this time.But this does not include those who are shielding and on the clinically extremely vulnerable list.Also on June , the sex ban has also been scrapped for those living alone, so partners in separate homes can sleep together once again.Mr Johnson confirmed last night that zoos and safari parks will be reopening on Monday.Meanwhile, non-essential shops will also be able to open their doors once again as of June .And places of worship will be allowed to open for inidual prayers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: kids schools february winter changes r number
story: Earlier this week the Government dropped plans for all primary school kids to go back for a month before the summer.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesInstead its now the aim for all kids - both primary and secondary - toby September for the start of the new academic year.Boris Johnson said yesterday its his ambition to get all children back in the classrooms.But the rate of infection was not yet low enough to get everyone in.Class sizes have been capped at and will prove a limitation to getting more kids in.However, earlier this week Matt Hancock admitted it was still uncertain they will be able to go back for September as planned.The Health Secretary signalled pupils might be stuck at home for months to come, with secondary schools reopening in September at the earliest”.And one official at the heart of coronavirus-making policy told The Spectator that the fearedschools were not opened by September then they could be pushed back into next year: If Sage are this cautious going into summer, then they are not going to want to play fast and loose with the R number heading into winter.Education Select Committee chair Robert Halfon told The Sun: We have to get these children learning again.If schools dont open in September, we will have an ice age in terms of childrens learning.There will always be a reason not to open schools, butit’s not impossible, theres a way to do it.Today No said that the Nightingale hospitals would be kept for the meantime, amid fears of a renewed wave of the virus over the winer.The Prime Ministers official spokesman said the hospitals remained an important surge capacity.We may still need Nightingale hospitals for the months ahead. We will maintain that extra capacity until such time as there is more certainty, the spokesman added.Yesterday, Government scientists revealed their fears of a deadly second wave in the winter which could throw a spanner in the works to kids education and the wider recovery,Sir Patrick said last night that scientists were looking carefully at how lockdown was managed should this happen again in the winter.Professor Whitty said: We have to accept that we could find ourselves in one of three situations.One is where we have a situation wherestarts to escape control.The aim is that wevery slowly to prevent that from happening but thats the risk.The second situation isand we all think there is a a reasonable chance that in the winter this virus will have some advantages it doesnt have the rest of the year.Its something that transmits more easily indoors.Therefore, things that are working well in summer and autumn may cease to be working as well in winter.The nature of new epidemics is very often they come in waves, circling around the world andwe get hit by another wave.At that point we need to understand better what is the optimal mix of things we can do.One of the Governments key tests for lting lockdown is ensuring the NHS will be able to cope - but as the nights start to draw in and more people fall ill with regular winter viruses, the health service could start to falter again.Today No said again that the threat level for the virus had not reduced down from four to three as was predicted.Some moves to ease the lockdown have been made - such as reopening schools for some pupils and plans to open shops next week - but that is because Boris Johnson has ensured the five tests have been met. To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: locals tape street sign named colston bristol
story: Blue tape has been plastered over the Colston Road sign in Bristol and a suggestion box has been installed below asking for new name ideas.Residents said they wanted a name that reflected the erse and inclusive feel of the area.Colston Road resident Dan Stone said: Who wants to live in a street named after a slave trader This is a multicultural area, we like that about it. It [the slave trade] is not something we want to celebrate.Businessman Abdul Malik said: Bristol is a city of inclusion - a city that provides sanctuary for refugees and asylum seekers.[But] when you drive around Bristol, its quite embarrassing to see places like Blackboy Hill and Whiteladies Road, and Colston being celebrated.Times have changed, and what was seen to be acceptable and normal at one time cant be seen to be acceptable at this time.Easton is erse and inclusive and I think it makes sense to rename that particular road to something that encapsulates that, rather than Mr Colston.Meanwhile a -year-old portrait of Colston was today removed from the Lord Mayors parlour at Bristols City Hall.The toppling of the statue of Colston in Bristol on Sunday has led to demands for other historic monuments to be removed.The statue was pulled down amid worldwide protests triggered by the death of George Floyd. It was fetched from Bristol harbour this morning. A website called topple the racists has compiled a list of around  statues and other memorials across the UK it argues should be taken down, because they celebrate slavery and racism.This includes th-century slave owner Sir Thomas Picton, th-century colonialist trader Robert Clive and th-century merchant Elihu Yale who had links to the slave trade.Campaigners have also challenged memorials to Sir Robert Peel, founder of the Met Police in London and former prime minister William Gladstone.The statue of slave owner Robert Milligan was removed from West India Quay in Londons Docklands on Tuesday night.London Mayor Sadiq Khan has also announced a new commission to review the capitals landmarks.In Oxford, hundreds gathered on Tuesday evening to demand the fall of a statue of Victorian imperialist Cecil Rhodes.In Edinburgh, a petition has been launched to remove the statue of slave owner Henry Dundas in St Andrew Square and for streets bearing his name to be renamed.Police officers with full riot gear will be on standby this weekend kitted up and ready to go amid fears of potential clashes between far-right extremists and anti-racism activists. Busloads of fans attached to firms at ious football clubs are planning to travel hundreds of miles to defend monuments after a number were vandalised during the Black Lives Matter demos.There are fears hundreds are planning to attend a patriotic unity event at Churchills statue in Westminster on Saturday morning.The Democratic Football Lads Alliance, a network founded in  that claims to oppose terrorism and conserve British traditions, has told members to defend statues and war memorials.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: support bubbles lockdown single people
story: The Prime Minister revealed that single people living alone - or with children under  - can form a support bubble with another family or household.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesSo what are the rules, and who can you meet, and when The PM said on June : There are too many people, particularly those who live by themselves who are lonely and struggling with being unable to see friends and family.From this weekend we will allow single adult households, living alone, or single parents with children under , to form a support bubble with one other household.Anyone who lives alone at the moment will be able to form a new bubble with another household - of any size - from Saturday, June .It will mean grandparents who live alone can finally see their grandchildren again.And single parents with kids can form a bubble with another house too - so they can stay overnight, help with childcare or provide much needed support.Any lone parent with kids under  is classed as single.The new lockdown changes are thought to affect around to . million people across the country.No. You can visit them in their own home, stay overnight, and you dont need to stay apart.Basically, they can act as though they are a part of your householdYou can travel between their house and yours, or they can move in with your family.No, you can pick only one and see them as much as you like.You cant swap in and out of multiple households.However, you dont have to move in with your new bubble - its OK to travel back and forth to see them.This can technically be as far as you like, but officials stressed that having a local bubble would be better. Single people will have to pick just one household to visit - which could include the heartbreaking choice of which children or grandchildren to see.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.The Government does not advise that people should form bubblesthey are shielding because they are extremely clinically vulnerable.At the moment there are no changes for that guidance.Shielding Brits can now go outside but still must keep metres apart from everyone.Then the whole bubble will have to isolate together for  days. Anyone who develops symptoms should be tested for the virus.Only in England at the moment.Nicola Sturgeon in Scotland has suggested that she is looking at social bubbles for people north of the border, but its not yet been announced.So far Wales and Northern Ireland have no confirmed plans for bubbles yet either.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: london south east north west furlough scheme
story: In a geographical breakdown of where people across the UK have been furloughed, the numbers were highest in these areas.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesMore than one million were put on the coronavirus job retention scheme in both London and the South West.And , were furloughed in the North West too.That compares to just , in the East Midlands, and , in Wales.In total nearly nine million people have been furloughed across the UK since March.Most of them were in the automobileor food services and accommodation sectorthe latest stats showed.About , were furloughed in manufacturing, and , in construction.Rishi Sunak, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said today: Our unprecedented coronavirus support schemes are protecting millions of vital jobs and businesses across the whole of the United Kingdom - and will help ensure we recover from this outbreak as swtly as possible.We have extended both schemes so they will continue to provide measured support across the UK as we start to reopen the economy.Yesterday was the cut off date for applying for the furlough scheme - but those who are on it can continue to get funding support..million businesses have been able to claim up to  per cent pay for their workers, up to a maximum of £, per month.But in the next few months the scheme will wind down, before being completely shut by the end of October.Businesses will have to start paying towards their employees national insurance costs from August.And they will need to start topping up wages from September, where the Government support will taper away.Across the whole of the UK,  per cent of those potentially eligible for support through the separate self-employment scheme made a claim, with the average value of claim amounting to £,, HMRC said today..million people have made claims for grant support, totaling £.billion. Many businesses are expected to have to lay off workers, however, as hundreds of thousands of them have been shut for nearly three months.However, from next week shops will be able to open once again, and from July pubs and restaurants are expected to be able to .Outdoor attractions including zoos and theme parks will too be able to open their doors to customers in hopes of ing to a new normal.To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: schools wont open for key workers over summer
story: It comes after the Government kept schools open for the children of key workers during the Easter and half term breaks so they could carry on delivering vital services to the nation.However, there was no detail on whether there will be any schemes in their place - such as summer camps or holiday clubs.Yesterday Boris Johnson promised a big summer of catch up help for kids to help them deal with the impact of the coronavirus crisis.Were going to get all schools back in September  we possibly can .. but its going to be a big summer of catch up.Were going to keep making sure that kids get the remedial help that they need for the stuff that theyve missed for months and months to come so that they genuinely make up for lost time.More details will be revealed by the Education Secretary Gavin Williamson next week.No stressed today that such camps would last for the summer and beyond. And they did not specy they would be only for the most disadvantaged kids either, leaving the possibility that they could open for millions of children. At the moment grandparents cannot look after children unless they are part of the same household.From Saturday a grandparent or friend can come to help with childcare and form a social support bubble with another family - but onlythey are currently living alone. per cent of key workers have at least one child aged  or below, the IFS has said.Virtually all key workers – including  per cent of health workers and  per cent of education workers – are either without a partner or have a partner in work, who might not easily be able to look after their children. Around  million people are thought to be in a key worker profession - such as in the NHS, a teacher, or someone delivering vital services like food delivery workers.Former education secretary Lord Baker said today: School holidays should be cancelled this year.Teachers and children have already had too much holiday this year and shouldto learning throughout the summer.By September hundreds of thousands,not millions, of schoolchildren will have had no school experience for more than six months. That is shocking, and some of these pupils will never be able to catch up.He also called for the m rule to be reduced to just one, and for teachers and pupils to get daily tests.Education Select Committee Chair Robert Halfon told The Sun The Government have always said schools are going to close over the summer.But its all the more reason why we need an Alan Turning catch up programme to help them.If schools dont open in September, we will have an ice age in terms of childrens learning.However, while the disadvantaged children had to remain the priority, he suggested that the kids of key workers could be included in a summer camp system to help them be able to carry on working - and to keep children learning.I wouldnt turn any child away from learning, absolutely anyone, he added. To receive The Sun’s Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply ‘Like’ our Coronavirus page.Get Britain’s best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day – find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: meghan markle prince harry discussed megxit before marriage
story: The Duke and Duchess of Sussex made headlines with their bombshell announcement in January that they were quitting the Royal Family to become financially independent.But claims have today emerged that the couple started talking about plans for a le away from the Royal Family before they even got married.The reports are set to emerge in a new book about the couple which will be released in August. Finding Freedom - said to have been written with the couple’s knowledge - is also set to detail the couples plans for the future following their decision to quit the UK for a new le in LA.A source told The Sun Online: The book will explore the journey that Meghan and Harry went through in coming to the conclusion that they did. It will make clear that far from it being a snap decision that they took a long time to make it.The seeds of Megxit were sown before they even got married. The truth is that Harry had been deeply unhappy for a long time. And he and Meghan openly discussed going in a dferent direction well before they got married.”It comes after it was revealed the book will shatter the notion the American actress is the driving force behind the pair - and instead that it was Prince Harry who wanted to make the change.A publishing insider said: “That word ‘Megxit’ in particular has always angered Prince Harry. It gives the impression that the decision to walk away from the Royal Family was Meghan’s.“The reality is Harry drove that decision. The book will make that clear and explain why it had to happen. The truth is Harry had been unhappy for a long, long time.In the days after his shock announcement that he was stepping away from Royal le, Harry, , hinted at his anger that the finger had been pointed at his we for the decision.Speaking at a charity event he said: “Once Meghan and I were married, we were excited, we were hopeful, and we were here to serve.“For those reasons, it brings me great sadness that it has come to this. The decision that I have made for my we and I to step back, is not one I made lightly.“It was so many months of talks after so many years of challenges. And I know I haven’t always gotten it right, but as far as this goes, there really was no other option.”Contrary to reports, the book - published worldwide on August  - will not be detailing the  year old Suits star’s ongoing fallout with her dad Thomas.The authors - former showbiz journalist Omid Scobie and royal reporter Carolyn Durand - are said to have been given access to friends of the pair, as well as direct access to the Sussexes themselves.Meghan and Harry are now living in the US with their one-year-old son Archie.The couple moved to LA after initially relocating to Canada after revealing they were stepping back as royals.They still have a home in the UK, Frogmore Cottage, and have started to make payments from the £.million refurbishment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince andrew hiding lawyers epstein
story: The -year-old royal this week insisted he had offered to speak with American prosecutors over his friendship with paedophile Jeffrey Epstein.But the lawyer for Epsteins victims today declared no one is above the law as she accused the Duke of York of still hiding.Speaking to Good Morning Britain today, she said: Prince Andrew said months ago he would cooperate but he has failed to do that.Hes hiding behind his attorneys.She said that the public figure should be transparent, adding: Its time to meet with the investigators, and help my clients, the victims of Epstein, to get justice.Andrew is facing ongoing scrutiny over his links to convicted sex offender Epstein, who was at the centre of a web of sex trafficking and abuse before killing himself in jail last August.The Sun this week revealed that the US Department of Justice has filed a mutual legal assistance request to the Home Office - which formally asks for help to question the Royal.But the royals lawyers released an unprecedented statement, insisting he had offered to assist in the investigation three times.Blackfords LLP acting for the royal said: The Duke of York has on at least three occasions this year offered his assistance as a witness to the DOJ. Unfortunately, the DOJ has reacted to the first two offers by breaching their own confidentiality rules and claiming that the Duke has offered zero cooperation.In doing so, they are perhaps seeking publicity rather than accepting the assistance proffered.The Duke has always denied any improper behaviour over his relationship with Epstein, and strongly denies allegations he slept with sex slave Virginia Roberts when she was .But hours later, Geoffrey Berman, the US Attorney for the Southern District of New York hit back.In an explosive statement, Mr Berman Prince Andrew was seeking to ly portray himself to the public as eager and willing to co-operate with an ongoing federal criminal investigationHe said:has repeatedly declined our request to schedule such an interview, and nearly four months ago informed us unequivocally – through the very same counsel who issued today’s release – that he would not come in for such an interview.Sources have claimed Andrew may never cooperate with the probe while Mr Berman is in charge, reports the .Insiders insist that Andrew should remain a witness rather than a target in the federal investigation into Epstein.The source said: The Duke would have cooperated fully with Berman had he not chosen to make an example of him.Andrew stepped down as a senior royal after his disastrous Newsnight interview last November.During the interview, Andrew said he would help the US investigationhis “legal advice was to do so”.Alleged victim Virgina Roberts Giuffre says she was trafficked by Epstein to have sex with Andrew in London in .She described Andrew as “sweating profusely” at Tramp nightclub before having sex at Ghislaine’s Mayfair flat.Andrew later told Newsnight a “peculiar medical condition” meant he did not sweat.And he insisted he did not go clubbing, claiming he remembered because he had been at Woking Pizza Express earlier that day.He claims he has no recollection of ever meeting Giuffre and sources close to the Prince have even suggested a photo with his arm around Giuffre at Maxwell’s flat could have been faked.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: officials examining dominic cummings lockdown
story: NewsOfficials examining Dominic Cummings lockdown cottage find breaches of planning rulesDurham County Council found "historic breaches of planning and building control regulations" but said it was too late to take enforcement actionShareCommentsByTom WilkinsonDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  JUN Updated:,  JUN NewsBoris Johnsons aide travelled  miles to stay at his family property at the end of March " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Council officials have found historic breaches of planning rules after examining the family cottage Dominic Cummings stayed in during lockdown.Durham County Council received a string of complaints about the home Boris Johnsonaposs aide travelled  miles to stay in at the end of March. Now the council has said it found historic breaches of planning and building control regulations. But it did not say what those breaches were, and said no enforcement action would be taken because of a time limit on doing so. The council has referred separate complaintsin respect of non-payment of Council Tax to the Valuation Office for consideration and review.  The property on the outskirts of Durham City is where the Downing Street adviser stayed after he and his we suffered coronavirus symptoms. According to reports, his parents bought the farm in . Records on the county council planning portal show that permission was granted two years later for the erection of a pitched roof structure over an existing swimming pool. In subsequent years, permission has also been granted to fell trees.Complaints were made after journalist Alex Tfin analysed public documents and questioned whether the property had followed planning and Council Tax rules.Stuart Timmiss, head of development and housing at Durham County Council, said: We have now investigated the complaints regarding planning permission. While there have been historic breaches of planning and building control regulations, current legislation places a time limit on any enforcement measures and as a result no further action will be taken. The investigation concluded that the main house has not been sub-ided and that the residential use of an outbuilding for family accommodation does not require planning permission. However, advice has been provided in relation to building control. We have also looked into the complaints raised in respect of non-payment of Council Tax and will be passing our findings on to the Valuation Office for its consideration and review. Downing Street declined to comment today on the councilaposs statement.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A Tory minister has claimed the governmentaposs actions saved huge numbers of lives despite the UKaposs coronavirus death toll passing ,.Simon Clarke hit back after Neil Ferguson, a former top advisor to the government, said the toll could have been halvedlockdown began a week earlier. The MP insisted the government acted in good faith on scientic advice - and claimed the UK was particularly vulnerable because itaposs a travel hub. He said: Huge numbers of lives have been saved by the action the government has taken and the resilience and co-operation of the British people. But he admitted clearly some decisions are easier in hindsight. And he confessed striking a balance between peopleaposs lives and livelihoods was the whole story of the pandemic - despite Health Secretary Matt Hancock claiming there just isnapost a trade-off.It comes exactly  weeks after Boris Johnson claimed in  weeks we can turn the tide.Since then the UKaposs official death toll from confirmed COVID- cases has topped ,. It is over , cases when deaths from suspected cases are included. Prof Ferguson, who had to step down from scientic advisory group SAGE after breaking lockdown, led research that warned mitigating the virus alone would have cost , lives.  Days after his team produced that study, the UK government U-turned and decided to impose a full lockdown from March . The , death toll is clearly lower than the , that was feared. But it is more than double the , that the chief scientic advisor said would be a good outcome.And Prof Ferguson last night said the death toll could have been halved by entering lockdown a week earlier. He told MPs: The epidemic was doubling every three to four days before lockdown interventions were introduced. So had we introduced lockdown measures a week earlier, we would have then reduced the final death toll by at least a half.  Minister for Regional Growth and Local Government Mr Clarke claimed the UKaposs death toll was so high compared to other countries because the UK is a travel hub. He told Sky News: We should be clear we acted in good faith on the guidance that we received. “We were taking the best possible advice open to us at the time. I don’t think for a second that government failed to listen to our scientists. Askedthe scientists got it wrong, he said: I don’t think they did. “Britain was always going to be hugely exposed to this virus because of some of the features of our society. We are a global travel hub.”  He went on: “Clearly some decisions are easier in hindsight than they are at the time. That’s just the nature of responding to such an unprecedented crisis.” Boris Johnson is currently facing anger from both sides of the virus debate. The death toll is above that of many other countries - but Tory MPs and industry also accuse the government of moving too slowly out of lockdown. Plans to bring all primary school pupils in England back before the summer have been shelved, and the government is under pressure to cut the two-metre distance rule to help them reopen.  Last night Boris Johnson said: Of course weaposve got to learn lessons. But I just think that it is at this stage premature, thereaposs still too much that we donapost know. Chief Medical Officer Prof Chris Whitty warned last night: We are not at the end of this epidemic, not by a long shot. We are in the middle of it. But asked todaythe tide had been turned - as Boris Johnson said it would be by now,  weeks ago - Mr Clarke said: I think it has. I thinkyou look both at the number of new infections and new deaths, they are coming down sharply, he said.  As lockdown is eased, ministers have insisted there is no trade-off between the economy and protecting peopleaposs lives. Health Secretary Matt Hancock said this week: It is just simplistic to say that there is a trade-off between the economy and health. Yet Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty last night said: Anyone who pretends there is a comfortable option has not understood the situation we’re in. We are obviously having, in government, to balance a large number of risks. What you are trying to do is manage those risks as best we can with the information we have to minimise the risk for the bad outcome and to maximise the possibility of a good outcome. But the idea that there is some option that is completely safe and all fine is clearly not true.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailMost children with conditions such as asthma, diabetes, epilepsy do not need to continue shielding and could go back to school, according to new guidance.The Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Healthhas published a new list for doctors on who should continue to shield and who no longer needs to.The Government will take the list into account. It says many children with conditions such as cerebral palsy and scoliosis should no longer be shielded. It adds that the benefits of school in terms of access to therapies and developmental support outweigh the risk of infection. It said: Children and young people who are cared for just in primary care are very unlikely to need to continue to shield.Do you have a coronavirus story to tell  Email webnew@mirrorThe RCPCH has created two lists, with those on List A being advised to continue to shield. These include children with immunodeficiency and immunosuppression, such as those who have had transplants, children having cancer treatment for acute leukaemia and Non-Hodgkinaposs Lymphoma. Children with signicant impairment in their ability to cough and to clear their airways are also on the list.  On the other hand patients on List B can discuss with their doctors whether it is safe for them to stop shielding, and, for example,to school when these reopen. This includes children with some cardiac conditions, those with sickle cell disease and children who were born premature with oxygen requirements. Those with kidney disease, cystic fibrosis or more serious asthma are also included on the B list.  Dr Liz Whittaker, co-author of the guidance for the RCPCH, said: There is a group of children who are very clinically vulnerable, and they should continue to shield. There is a second group who are currently shielding but may not need to do so. Itaposs important for parents and carers to have a conversation with their specialist to determine the best course of action. These conversations will be informed by knowledge of the severity of the disease, intensity of the treatment, and, for some, their home situation. We need to get the balance right between clinical risks and the social impact of shielding.  We know this has been a tough period for lots of children, young people, and their loved ones. This guidance is to help doctors have evidence-based discussions with parents and carers. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAn artist who spent more than  years turning her cottage into a aposle-size dolls houseapos says her eccentric style of bright interior decoration has scared off any potential buyers. Mary Rose Young has been putting her own touches on the beautul country home in Lydney, Gloucestershire, by hand since , when she purchased the property for just £,. After  years in the house, she put it up for sale in  and estate agents told her that she could expect it to fetch at least £, from prospective buyers. But her hopes of selling up to open a boutique hotel nearby were dashed when only one person could be persuaded to view the house, with Mary Rose saying they aposleft pretty quicklyapos. Despite the decor leaving Mary Rose and her husband Phil Butcher stuck in the home, the -year-old potter has refused to paint over her leaposs work and says she still loves her home, which she also uses as a workspace and gallery. She said: I made this house around my own le and I wasnapost thinking about it being sellable. Weaposre living like two children in a dollaposs house and in retrospect why would anybody  want to buy it  Itaposs like a playhouse for adults. I just thought it might go to a mad collector of my work who might want to buy it, but no one was interested.  Only one person came and looked at it in the year it was on the market and they werenapost here long. I think they had just come out of curiosity to see the decoration and were never interested. The estate agents despaired. I could have painted over all my work, but I didnapost want to. I love my house and the house really works for me. Iaposm a colourful person and I even have pink hair. I like it more and more as I get older.  Since the failure to sell left her dreams of running her own hotel in tatters, Mary has doubled down and put even more effort into putting her mark on the property, turning the courtyard into a bright pink painting studio last year. When she originally bought the house, which is comprised of two knocked-through cottages, she painted the entire home white in a bid to bring more light in, but when that failed she began drawing patterns inspired by her colourful pottery on the walls.  She said after doing one wall orange with red dots it helped distract from the fact thereaposs aposhardly any natural lightapos and it went from there. She added: It became a really fun project for me on the side of my pottery business and I was so galvanised by it I ended up neglecting my pottery at times. Mary Rose has also incorporated her pottery pieces into the homeaposs features, with a pottery chandelier in the sitting room and handmade pottery tiles in the bathroom.

story: NewsI forgot my children, what racism was and how to walk and talk after car crashElizabeth Boudreaux, from Swansea, forgot what racism was after she lost all her memories in a crash in , meaning she had to be re-introduced to her two childrenShareCommentsByLucy JohnMatthew Dresch:,  JUN NewsElizabeth Boudreaux with her daughters Sarahand Sian " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mum is rebuilding her world after a car crash wiped her memory of her children and previous le. Elizabeth Boudreaux, , was pronounced dead five times after the horric smash in  - and had to learn to walk and talk again. When she woke up from a coma she was unable to remember anything before the incident, Wales Online reports. She has now spoken out about the moment her mother re-explained racism to her after she noticed people looking at her like a aposfish in a fishbowlapos on display. Speaking following the death of George Floyd, Elizabeth, who has British and Nigerian heritage, said racism is still an issue in Swansea.She said: I went to college after my accident to study counselling. I wanted to do something good and educate myself. A staff member told a story in front of a group of us and said the reason why black people are black is because they donapost wash. I was shocked and confused and everyone was looking at me. It was like I was a fish in a fishbowl on display. I remember feeling unwell that day and afterwards I cried and cried and cried to my mother, who is originally from Nigeria. She explained to me that this is racism and that it has always been around. When I experienced this disgusting behaviour I was in extreme shock I had no idea humans were so cruel to one another.  It might have been the first memory Miss Boudreaux has of racism but it certainly wasnapost her last. She explained that since the Black Lives Matter movement has come to the forefront of debate, she has seen a number of people dismiss suggestions that racism happens in Swansea and other parts of Wales. Racism does exist in Swansea. I myself have experienced it many times, said Elizabeth, who lives in Killay. A few years ago I was in my own front garden doing some weeding and I saw someone with two horses, one white and one brown, over the fence.  They said, while looking at me and laughing: aposYou know, you get white and brown horses tooapos. I just stopped what I was doing and ran back inside. Another time I was in a taxi and was askedIaposm married. I said: aposNo, I have a partnerapos. He said: aposHeaposs black is he apos I said: aposNo, heaposs whiteapos. To that the man responded: aposOh, so you donapost bed your own do you apos. I was in complete disbelief. Elizabeth said she had even witnessed children using racial slurs in Swansea. A child, about the age of five, once called one of my children aposblackieapos while they were out playng. A parent apologised but you think: aposWhere did that child learn it from in the first place apos  Hearing the aposNapos word in music and film really upsets me. I thinkpeople are still using it like that people are going to think itaposs okay. Iaposve heard my childrenaposs friends playing it and all I can hear is that word. I canapost listen to it. Elizabeth said racist comments and experiences build up, making her feel like she canapost always trust people. It gets me really, really down. Itaposs just heartbreaking since Iaposve learnt how people are, I feel like some people donapost like me because of my skin colour, she said. I donapost knowpeople are being . When people are being nice to my face are some of them also going home and saying these horrible things about me   In group conversations people sometimes stare at me and other times they wonapost even acknowledge me but they always talk to my partner. It just makes me feel like Iaposm a person as well, why canapost they speak to me the same  Sometimes itaposs just the way people are around me, keeping a distance, and Iaposm there thinking: aposDo I smell or something apos She also recalled situations where people had been hostile towards her and said based on her experiences she could only conclude it was because of the colour of her skin.  To think that in the st century this is still happening it appalling. I feel sick to my stomach. I think of people like my mother and grandmother when I see racism and what they and other people have experienced in their lives. Itaposs dehumanising and degrading, she said. At the end of the day weaposve all got red blood pumping through our veins. Itaposs not black, white, or any other colour of the rainbow. Itaposs red. Elizabeth had to be reintroduced to her two daughters – Sian, now , and Sarah,  – after her crash because she could not remember them.
